review_title: Not as good as I was hoping...
review_text:
ACTUALLY ITS A VERY MILD SPOILER To be honest, I really, really want to like this movie, and I do...sort of.

It does stay pretty true to the book, they even plucked lines straight out of the novel...although some lines could have just stayed in the book as far as I was concerned (there's just no way to use the lion and lamb line without being cheesy, this film proves that). There were some fairly minor deviations from the book, but honestly nothing to get in a snit over. My major beef is that while Stephenie didn't talk down to the readers, the movie did. It just seemed that it was made solely for the 16 year old set, and unfortunately anyone older has a harder time sitting through it. The thing is that the book is more about the love story between Bella and Edward with a villain(s) chucked in at the end; the movie tried to make it more about the threat of the Nomadic vampires against Bella, so we ended up with a really abbreviated love story.

On to the acting (or over-acting)...I wont lie there is no shortage of cheese in this movie. Some of the lines, and the way they are delivered, just make your eyes roll. People in the theater were laughing more about how things were being said than any real humor in the dialogue.

I've come to the grim realization that I HATE Kristen Stewart as Bella, she does this annoying huffing after almost every line! It was beyond annoying, I just wanted to smack her upside the head for each eye roll, shrug and huff she delivered. She made Bella look and feel like such a ditz. I don't know if Kristen had trouble remembering her lines and therefore had to have these huffs and pauses to give herself time to think or what her goal was, but it didn't work for me.

Surprisingly, however, I loved Taylor as Jacob, which is weird because I didn't like his character, nor did I think the actor suited the part; so I'm happily wrong there. Billy Burke and Gil Birmingham (Charlie Swan and Billy Black) were fantastic. Kellen Lutz is perfect as Emmett and even Nikki Reed makes a good bitchy Rosalie. I can't have much of an opinion about the other Cullen actors as they didn't have enough lines nor screen presence to make much of an impression on me (except Jasper, who as Jessica line points out, "looks like he's in pain").

Rachelle Lefevre (Victoria) was also fantastic, she was way better than Cam Gigandet (James) and Edi Gathegi (Laurent).

And let's give it up for the humans! They were much funnier and less cheesy than the vampires (although I didn't like the take on Angela, she's supposed to be shy not a carbon copy of Jessica) The special effects left much to be desired (I HATE the glitter effect). They looked just too cheap and hokey for my tastes, but it's a low budget film, I wasn't really expecting a whole lot there.

I was surprised at how well the soundtrack was incorporated into the movie. I am one of those people who bought the soundtrack and to be honest I really only like four of the songs, and for the life of me I couldn't figure out how the hell any of the other songs were going to fit in the movie, but they did a very good job with it. Supermassive Black Hole during the baseball scene was perfect! Oh, I do have to say that I agree with Stephenie, the end credits were awesome.

review_title: I adore the book, but the movie was not an instant love.
review_text:

But I did not feel the same of the movie not at first sight, But after I had reviewed twilight again the second . I fell in love with the movie. best regard

This movie was terrible.

Reasons:

1. Vampires cannot go into the sunlight because they will sparkle (their skin glitters in the sun.. this is the only effect the sun has on them - no harm done whatsoever).

2. The vampires claim to be "vegetarian", so they eat animals instead of humans.

3. The vampires play baseball in their free time. (self-explanatory)

4. The lead character (vampire) spends half of the movie running around the forest like a chimpanzee, carrying around some girl. Its terribly cheesy and its obvious he's got a crotch-harness on that whole time. (there's nothing to smash) It's some scene that should be left in Tarzan.

5. With pretty much no explanation at all, the main character (vampire) has the ability to read minds.

6. The movie has events that are entirely stupid - time and time again.

ie. Vampire pitches the ball to vampire batter.. vampire batter hits the ball and it flies 5 miles out. Vampire outfielder waits.. (because he knows he's just that fast) and then runs out there (faster than the ball) and gets the ball. He throws the ball back to home plate. (somehow the vampire batter can't run around the bases before the outfielder runs 5 miles).

Most demented of all, why would the vampire THROW the ball back when he JUST DEMONSTRATED that it would be faster to run the ball back and tag the runner. (Not to mention it makes no sense that he can run faster than a ball that was hit with a bat) The movie is simply irritating with its nonsensical garbage and terrible special effects. Not to mention it craps all over the established vampire genre with its sparkling, vegetarian, tree-climbing, base-ball-playing vampire BS. There is pretty much no mention of wooden stakes, crosses, garlic, fangs, bats or anything other than lame vampires that sparkle in the sunlight.

review_title: special, and it could't be better.
review_text:
Firstly, i am a straight male 23 years of age. I say this because I try and give this review from my point of view as such, mainly in response to the negative review by "ctg0724".

It is true that the main characters (ie. vampires) in this film are presented as 'not realistic' but that is the whole idea.

If you've read the books, the entire story is basically (without wanting to stereotype) but a version of every girl's dream!

No guy in history could ever live up to Edward, i wont give away spoilers, but read the books and watch the films and you'll see why, I would strongly argue that the main reason despite super abilities is actually his patience.

I thought the books were fantastic as a no holds barred vision of what real girls really want (if you are intelligent enough to look past the supernatural things that make it entertainment, and to the actual fantasy ideas beneath, ie. romance-a lot of which is expressed in many ways throughout, the fact that he gives her so much attention, reassurance, patience, money (haha despite her 'objections' to it) and the love of family. (Also notice that all the men are very manly men, aggressive, strong, masculine types (female writer quirk))

These are very real and attainable things to us all, but obviously set in a story to make it interesting media. Don't get me wrong, I am aware that in the current world its hard- almost impossible for average Joe to have money and give a girl all your time!

For the actual film, i'd say it does well to tell the book, and i think the cinematography was FANTASTIC and SO BEAUTIFULLY SHOT, it was one of the things that made me get into the twilight series. The sense of discord at the beginning i found very effective and uncomfortable, in a good way, and some of the scenery for the supernatural showing off was simply breathtaking.

With so many male directors out there who focus on male things like the action in the story, i felt that having a female director and a female writer make the focus of the film very 'different' but that couldn't be a better thing, its so refreshing for mainstream and i thought Twilight was brilliant.

review_title: If you liked the books you'll like the film.
review_text:
If you liked the books, then you will like the film. I didn't think going into the movie I would say but coming out of it that is the only thing to be said. The film did an excellent job of sticking to the book and showing the speedy relationship between Bella and Edward. While a few darlings were killed (great parts in the book not shown on screen) it still captured the essence with beautiful music (something dear to the character of Edward) and an amazing real life Washington state backdrop and two brooding teenagers in love. And like I said, if you liked the books this visual embodiment of book may turn out to be well worth your cash and two hours of your time to see your literary fantasy come alive.

If you didn't like the books your enjoyment of the film really lies in your enjoyment of the genre, romance, fantasy, action. If you don't like that combination IE "The Convenant", "Van Helsing", "Underworld" etc and ilk of the like, then you wont like this movie at all.

The film does have some dragging moments, but for someone like myself dying to see it, it was an opportunity to relax and enjoy. For someone who didn't read the books and doesn't like the genre, all this movie would do for you is drag.

Overall I say the film was a great and an honest adaptation of the book made for FANS ONLY.
5 minutes in and I can tell this is the worst movie I'll ever see. Why is there a boy carrying a bag of boiled eggs around with no explanation? Is this a comedy?

After having read the four-volume Twilight Saga (and enjoying EVERY word of it!), I was thrilled to see the movie, "Twilight" and again, I enjoyed EVERY minute of it!

Unlike the almost word-for-word, scene-for-scene writing of the Harry Potter movies, "Twilight" was shot allowing imagination and still getting across the messages of the book, Twilight, specifically Edward's resistance to "turning" Bella and her insistence that her love is more important than mortality, all while occasionally having Bella, speaking in first person, narrating aloud during the movie.

The special effects were spectacular and there was a definitive lead-in to the next movie and I AM looking forward to it! And the actors selected to portray the Cullen family/coven: STUNNING! AND I look forward to seeing them in the future movies!

review_title: Made the Gong Show look like top talent
review_text:
So, so very bad. Robert Pattinson, the male lead, is made-up like the Avon Lady. Nikki Reed looks like one of the black guys in White Chicks and Kristen Stewart was as wooden and flat as a living human being can possibly be. The special effects are not equal to 50's TV and the script was painful to hear. Perhaps that is why the actors performed on something equal to middle-school level.

The sooner this tasteless little flick fades away, the better.

I assume Summit is rushing to complete the rest of the movies before the fan base grows up and develops some sense of taste.

Oh well, you can't make a silk purse from a sow's ear.

I literally have tears in my eyes from laughing as I write this review. Don't get me wrong, I love the Twilight book series very much and I've read them countless times. But these movies... especially this one, Twilight, are just SO awful that it's actually funny. I feel so bad for the actors who had to do this lol especially Robert Pattinson who I know is very aware of how bad they are. I'm leaving this review mostly to HOPEFULLY spread interest in remaking the Twilight story into a premium channel series. One that is actually a well representation because I cannot stress this enough... this movie is comically bad.

Let me just say that Twilight was the closest I will probably EVER come to a Horror/Scary movie. It was mysterious, yes, but also a bit corny at times. I noticed Bella was as pale, if not paler, than all the Cullens/Hales. It was so not an attractive trait of her character. Jessica, Angela, Mike, and Eric were exactly the kind of friends you NEED in (a new) high school, but Bella is a total loner. I loved the friends' characters, but they were way too perky for Bella's type, I guess. Oh yeah, and I have to say the best part of the whole movie was Jacob Black played by Taylor Lautner!!!! No offense to the other characters, of course. I can hardly wait to see that hottie turn in to a wolf!! New Moon is going to rock!! I'M SO EXCITED!!

Critics have been giving lukewarm reviews of Twilight for a lack of action, blood and gore. My question to them is "Have you read the books?" The book is a love story about a girl who falls in love with a boy who happens to be a vampire and the obstacles they need to overcome. Granted the movie wasn't perfect but with a budget of only 37 million, I think they did a darn good job representing the book, also the movie has Stephenie's blessing. Does it follow the book precisely, no, but what book to movie adaption ever does? The movie stays true to the essence of the characters and the story. If they fit the whole book into the movie, that would be a four hour movie, now, being an avid Twilight fan, I wouldn't have minded that one bit.

There were a few scenes in the movie where I felt the actors could have enunciated their lines a bit more clearly, also some of the "glowering" scenes were a bit over the top being laughed at by the audience. But was that the fault of Rob overacting or Catherine's fault for lack of direction? (maybe I should try to glower with orange contacts in my eyes) I felt the movie flowed well with the bit of tweaking done from book to script. I would have liked to see the part at the caf√©' in Port Angeles where Bella tells Edward to stop dazzling people and him asking her if he dazzles her to which her answer is "Frequently" If you read Midnight Sun on Stephenie Meyer's website that is a pivotal turn for Edward. I felt that was important.

When Edward enters the sunlight, it has more of a glittery look. Perhaps a better look would have been that of an opal with the rainbows reflecting off him? (I saw on another post site that several people agreed with my opal look for the vampires) I could have done without the "sparkle" sound affect in the movie. Tell me, does a Swarovski crystal make a sound when it catches the sunlight and sparkles? I just thought it was a cheesy addition.

I would have liked to see Edward dedicate Bella's lullaby to her and hear it in its pure form, just the piano, Edward and Bella.

The kiss scene in Bella's room was so electric you could feel the tension building in your own body and when their lips finally consummated their love... WOW! There is definitely a powerful chemistry between these two actors bringing more to this movie than if they didn't.

I liked the scenes of James' coven hunting bringing more depth to the "bad" vampires. Collecting mementos from their prey was brilliant.

I enjoyed it for what it is. A book to movie adaption and a getaway from the real world for two hours that I liked VERY much.

review_title: If you have never read the book...
review_text:
Before I tear into this movie, I just wanted to say, I know what the director and producer were going for with this movie. They wanted an artsy-type film that followed the book in as many of the important areas as possible. They wanted the acting and make-up to be over-dramatic and scenes to be very surreal. They tried to pull it off, but it didn't quite turn out as planned.

I went to this without having read the book. I saw the previews, and it looked pretty sweet. I was pumped up for the movie, and then it started, and it went downhill from there. First of all, the make-up is HORRIBLE. I understand they are vampires, but Edward and his buddies look like they are straight out of an 80's music video with WAY too much lipstick. Second, the special effects were something straight out of network TV (comparable to Buffy the Vampire Slayer). I'm not saying there is anything wrong with the special effects on network TV, but they have a pretty limited budget to work with. A movie that was going to be HUGE should have had a slightly bigger budget to spend on special effects. The next thing I found sub-par was the overly-cheesy romantic dialogue. They were trying to keep with the text from the book, but certain things just sound better when you read them. All in all, the movie was a complete let down, and should have been a straight to DVD release.

The last thing I am going to say is that I almost guarantee there will be a sequel to this movie. The book has such a huge fan base that even with a movie directed and produced like this, they will make bank. They will try to capitalize on the next book and will probably make just as much on the next movie. All I hope for is that they stray from the text just slightly so it is not quite as cheesy and spend a little more on the special effects. And if it isn't too much to ask, fire the director, producer, and anyone else associated with the production of the first movie.

As Edward Cullen's half naked body gleams with crystals as he stands in the sun of a seemingly mythical forest, he smiles. He says that this is why vampires throughout the ages can't be seen in the sun. At this point, I think I understood what kind of movie this was supposed to be.

I had seen the TV spots for Twilight, and heard of how great the books were, but never really knew what all the fuss was about. A few of my friends said that the movie was a must-see (unsuprisingly, they were without a Y chromosome). Next thing I knew, I was taken in a theater with hundreds of screaming high school girls, being force fed little known facts about every one of the characters.

As a movie, from someone who has never touched one of the books, it fails pretty horribly. Apart from some truly beautiful scenery, there's really nothing to savor in this film. Robert Patterson and Kristen Stewart are decent in the lead performances, showing that they really do have some potential with better direction. The supporting actors, however, were uniformly terrible. The "bad" vampires and young werewolves were especially horrendous.

I saw where this movie was trying to go, but it desperately needed a better director. The movie seems to mock the audience's intelligence, flashing back to earlier parts of the movie many times to remind us what happened. After about the halfway point, I completely lost interest in where the story was going. Unless you're an avid fan of the books, this is definitely not worth the $9 admission.

Twilight was one of the films I have been waiting to see for over eight months and it was worth twelve dollars however even if its interesting, it did in some parts feel hollow.

Robert Pattinson plays Edward Cullen, an 108 year-old vampire who only eats on animal blood instead of humans. Robert took awhile to get into Edward's shoes but eventually he got in and showed his side of Edward. Kirsten Stewart was magnificent as Bella Swan, she showed a isolated side not shown before and it makes you feel as though you are her. In some parts.

The special effects were so bad that it looks as though, the film was sped up to make the vampires look faster. And especially when they were running, it looks as though they were on a running platform. It looked so silly.

The landscape and location were so beautiful. I was awe-d by them and they were such a delight, showing a light side but also a dark side. The soundtrack was a delight too, it fitted too well into the movie, I rushed out and brought the soundtrack.

The film felt more of a comedy at times than an action romance. Especially when Bella hit Jacob with the door or when Edward nearly barfed when he first sensed Bella. It was enjoyable though, had some laughs. An action, comedy, romance, thriller.

Twilight is an enjoyable popcorn film. It has plot holes and lost big chunks from the book but it still delivered what I expected and it was worth it. So i would watch it for both hard-core fans or people just wanting to see a film.

8/10

I really enjoyed this movie, especially after reading the books.My friends and I were stuffed in a packed cinema with only a few seats to spare. The movie was extraordinary, different to all the films i have ever seen and trust me I have watched a lot of movies.It was a totally amazing movie with horror scenes and romantic,heartwarming scenes.It is a joy ride from start to finish.I really liked the sound effects and a great full cast. Bella Swan,Kristen Stewart,a teenager falls in love with a vampire named Edward Cullen,Robert Pattinson. They both enjoy each others company,unfortunately Edward is way to worried about Bella because of the other vampires who are out there hunting for Bella. So she moves from her town named Forks and goes back to where she came from,phoenix,after a brutal attack between her and James, Bella decides to move back to Forks to stay with her beloved Edward.

All i can say about this movie is that it is like a board, in other words its like someone telling you a story but keeping at the same pace all the way through. No excitement or any parts that keeps you on the edge of your seat. I haven't read the book yet but i believe if this was directed by someone with better potential the movie will be more than just a chick's flick. I don't know if either the director was fired or not but its a good they changed it to Paul Weitz (American Pie, Golden Compass). I believe he'll most probably will do a better job. However i'm looking forward to the third movie directed by David Slade (30 days of night). That is what a vampire movie should be. 30 days of night was a simple but entertaining flick.

Also the actors especially the main actress i'm looking forward to the day she wins an Oscar (if she ever will even get close to any nominations). All the way through the movie its like she's repeating the same actions over & over. They should just get her to act one scene then reuse that scene all the way through the movie.

For me i don't really care much about the acting or the actors in a movie as long as they suit their characters (dont' expect them to be Oscar winners) because the actors/actresses only have about 10% impact on the movie. Most important is getting the RIGHT DIRECTOR telling the story in a way that keeps the audience coming out pleased.

review_title: Not as bad as people make out.
review_text:
Now I won't go on about the characters or the plot. I read the first book in high school the year it came out and my feeling were "meh". I'd read dozens of its ilk and saw nothing special. I'm now a few years over the target demographic, so you can guess what I think.It is what it is. Broody vampire meets bland teen. Not an awful contribution to the urban fantasy world.

The acting is fine. Stewart has a confidence that compensates for her character's lack of a spine, Pattinson's lack of expression fits the undead theme and Lautner...Well, with a face like that, who really cares?

But the young cast, cardboard cut-out characters, and lightweight plot are all completely outshined by the cinematography. The photography is absolutely scrumptious. The directing was different and added a rougher, younger edge and overall changed the feeling.

This could have been Gossip Girl with fangs, but instead you have a darker, less glossy, but more vibrant feel.

I am a huge die hard fan on the Twilight series. I was so excited to this film, I have been waiting for it all year long, and after I was done watching it I was so surprised that it was so reliable to the book. However they did miss some parts and added new parts, but it's hard to put a 498 page book into a two hour movie.

The actors did a pretty good job and the plot was decent, however I feel like in the end they rushed things a little bit. But like I said, they're trying to put a 498 page book into a two hour film.

Even though some people didn't really like this movie, they shouldn't compare this movie to the novel so much, because it's a great film, even though I felt like the film got to my expectations. You won't be disappointed with this film. 9/10

Went to see this because of a girl. Left the girl because she stood up and screamed like every other girl at the theatre. You'd have thought it was an NSYNC concert. Every thing about this movie is bad. The story is litterly about a vampire who is hundreds of years old falling in love with a teenage girl. He takes her to meet his vampire family who refuse to drink blood. Not quite sure how that works. Then some how in the same town there are also werewolves disguised as native Americans. Guess what the two don't like each other and want to fight. But the girl wants to get with both vampire guy and wolf boy. Then they throw in vampires that want to drink blood. This movie proves teenage girls will watch anything if there's a cute guy in it. Poor story telling meets over and under acting mixed with weird choices. The oddest part of this movie was that the girls father was the best and most compelling character in the film. If it had just been about him taking out vampires and wolves it may have had a chance. But it is what it is a ploy to sell sex with much older men to highschool girls.

When I went to go see Twilight I automatically assumed that it was going to be a horrible spoof of the much loved book that I have read many times.But surprisingly, it was brilliant.I don't really like some of the casting decisions that they have made, like casting Kirsten Stewert as Bella. But Edward being played by Robert Patterson is a work of genius.The fight scene actually really scared me and James was brilliant in his part. Also, I really hated Rosilie. As in, she was acted so well, that I wanted to kill her her for being so mean to Bella. I will be extremely glad to buy it on DVD when it comes out and will support Catherine Hardwicke to make the next three movies. I would recommend it to Twilighters and Non-Twilighters alike. My advice, go see it. And if you already have, go see it again and support the industry!

These films are great for your usual teenagers who find it a chore to find love and fantasise about the characters instead. For me though, it was atrocious. Even Robert Pattinson said in a review that he hated twilight. Look it up. In my opinion, Kirsten Stewart can't act. She reminds me of Rowan Atkinson in the very first season of Blackadder which nearly got stopped there. For those of you who have never seen the first Blackadder season, Rowan Atkinson's character was a mixed person basically. It was as if he had multiple personalities and it was way over the top. To me, Kirsten doesn't know how she wanted to act in the film. She always seemed confused. Oh, btw Twilight is a perfect example of what not to do. When a guy like Edward treaats you like crap as he did, go for the one who was always there and put up with your emotional ass. In my opinion, she f***ed around with Jacob's feelings.

This movie had a terrible director in my opinion. The movies were bogus. My advice is to read the books. They were a hell of a lot better than the movies, I know. I've read them all.

Hated them.

When this came out I was 9 and I absolutely loved it. Now I'm thirteen and I don't find it as good as what I used to. I think that it has a good story-line with some good actors. I say good because it was OK but not outstanding. My favourite character in the film would be Charlie, played by Billy Burke. I think you have to be either a woman or about 11 to like this because every boy I know absolutely hates it. This is better than New Moon but I would say that It's not as good as Eclipse. Overall I would say that Twilight is a good film (especially if you like Robert Pattinson!) with a good story-line. I would rate it 7/10 and say that it is suitable for anyone 8+.

I don't think this is a terrible movie. They got decent actors to portray the characters. I do like how it captures being a teenager pretty much spot-on. Kristen Stewart's character is quite odd and bipolar. It has sad elements. The plot is good enough for now. There will be a continuation off of this one so I'm more hopeful for that. I likes the actors chosen to portray the Cullen family. All perfect. All though the CGI is terrible, the character's dialogue is somewhat cringey at certain points, it can still be funny.

review_title: The Novel is much better than the movie
review_text: I can almost see huge differences between the novel and the movie about the dialogue , scenes , changed events and alot of things Also there are missing details that's why when someone see the movie without reading the novel he will not understand anything but few of them

review_title: Good for its world building, bad for itself
review_text:
Bella Swan, a seventeen year-old high school student moves to the state of Washington to her father after her mother marries a baseball player who travels a lot. Soon she gets to know the mysterious powers of Edward Cullen, her all-but-normal classmate. And so it all begins. T wilight is a very slow movie. It does a lot of world building and establishes the main characters of the saga, I understand that. I never read the books by Stephanie Meyer and I guess there are probably more dialogues in the book and Bella expressing her feelings in her thoughts. Just some things that are hard to transfer into a movie.

What makes the film even slower than it is, are the long but slow dialogues. I don't think they work very well. At least I couldn't really feel the attraction between them, all I saw were some teenagers awkwardly trying to talk to each other. The special effects are ok but I think that - especially in the ending scene - they could have polished the effects a little bit more. The casting is good. The one that in my opinion fits most into his role is Carlisle Cullen.

Twilight is a set-up movie for this world and in that regard it does well. But otherwise it's just very slow and at some points even boring.

As a fan of the series I assumed it would at least SLIGHTY resemble the book.. I guess I was wrong..

Half of what when done was inaccurate and the other half was rushed.. They took events that were supposed to "take place" over the course of 6/7 months and packed then into a 2 hr movie that played out like it was a week. Making the movie even more gag worthy.

This was a great concept (in theory) but would have been SOOOOO much better as a TV show. 1 book per season. AND WHO CAST THIS GARBAGE!!!..

So i don't know what else to say other than I WANT MY MONEY BACK!!

~ Disappointed in CT

Language.

Edward is supposed to be close to 100 yrs old, Carlisle's older. We should hear at least a few antique words, every now and then, from them, no matter how they might be trying to fit in. Stephenie Meyer used a few in her books, like "sanguine"... that one works. If you read a book like Will Self's "My Idea of Fun", you'll find that this is one of the things that really cranks up the creep factor with (in that book) The Fat Controller.

Anyway, I read the 1st three Twilight books last year and didn't want the story to end, so I put off reading the last one 'till now. I'm a Romantic. 'No apologies. After seeing the film, I couldn't stand it any longer: I had to dive into the dusty copy of "Breaking Dawn" that's been sitting on my night table stand for months now.

I was all prepared to not like this movie. I was even telling myself I didn't like it very much as I was watching it... then I realized, a day later, that I'd watched it three times.

Part of what drew me in, initially (with the books 1st, then the movie), was the setting: anyone who's been there knows that most of the movie was obviously filmed in and around Portland, OR. (Cannon Beach, the Three Capes, Multnomah Falls), but the entire Northwest is hauntingly beautiful. Just the thing for this kind of story. A few words more words on this: "Twin Peaks"... Neko Case.

Kristen and Robert are perfect as Bella and Edward. Period. I can't believe the folks responsible for it actually managed to find them. I also like Taylor as Jacob, but I'm with Charlie on Alice: Damn! Ashley Greene is a little more than perfect in this part. We're talking Gloria-Graham-level HOT, HOT, HOT!

But, back to the language thing: did I miss it or did Kristen/Bella not say "Holy Crow!" once in this movie? Jeeze, I know it might have been tough for the oh, so serious actress, but you gotta just let go and give in to your inner geek every now and then! Ya know?

Greetings all.

Before posting a comment on the movie I took the time to read on what other people thought of/about it and even though it was a film that I really looked forward to watching I got intimidated by the generally average/bad reviews it received. To my eyes the reviews spoke of a cheesy film, made for 15 year old girls which has no point whatsoever etc etc. Yet since I've taken time to watch some of the worst films of all history (Manos, hands of fate being the top one) I decided to go and watch it nonetheless setting my expectations to ground zero just in case. For the reviewer's record, I am a 29 year old guy whose favorite films list is populated by movies like schindler's list, the man with no name trilogy (fistful of dollars, fistful of dollars more, good bad ugly), rocky 1, gone with the wind, the green mile and of course the dark knight ! Not exactly a 15 year old girl's or boy's preferences :).

The movie was far from cheesy to begin with. It was a story told before, for sure, but the way it was portrayed and displayed was very elegant.

Main Actors. The chemistry between the two main stars is incredible; I am strongly considering watching the film again just to see them both play together. Easily to become one of the most loved couples of our times on the screen. Edward suffers from his predatory hunger for Bella's blood yet loves her very strongly at the same time. The pain and torn heart of his displays on his features in almost every bit of the way. The way he looks at her is truly both inhuman and deeply mortal in some manners truly capturing the idea of how an Immortal could love a mortal (at least in the way my mind perceives it). As for Bella, she is a very beautiful woman yet a quiet one. Not one to show off. Her face doesn't give away pride or arrogance. She ignores most of the world or the happenings around her and yet lets Edward inside. I think the two are brought together through their search of something different to the rest of the world. Or, in this case, their worlds. They really blend as one and all the scenes that the two participate in are beautiful and emotionally strong; it's the love we've all dreamed of from times to times yet few movies came close to doing honor to the book pages that stimulated our fantasy. This is one of the movies that pulls through.

Secondary crew.

Unfortunately, they come across as insignificant. Save for Bella's father who played his part nicely and lively, I don't remember a single high school person's name. It's a bit sad really because it feels like viewing two characters' deeply evolve and unravel their inner being and yet be surrounded by one-dimensional, shallow support crews. Bella's dad was good, the vampire family were...well didn't really have much to do. The high school gang was as if out of a teen-horror movie show; And jacob who supposedly plays a very strong part in the following books came across as hardly even a potential love interest to Bella. If I could improve something about this movie, it would be the surrounding characters' evolution and involvement in the story. Even the bad vampire was...Well, you knew he was there to get his ass kicked to be honest. He never felt like a threat or not really portrayed his motivations long or believably enough. Haven't read the book but I surely hope it's not like this !

Directing

Seriously, give the director a break. The way most of the reviews come across about how 'cheesy' it is to see Bella's hair fly at the fan, or to see Edward sparkle, or this or that. Made me feel like I was going to watch a comedy. But having the fan blow her hair and as such her blood's scent for him to take in and feel uncomfortable was a great moment while also introducing some well received humor in the intensity of the moment. We are talking about teen-love after all, do not forget !And disregarding the fact that vampires usually explode in sunlight, it was nice and...new. Keep an open mind to things and you won't be so disappointed in them. The scenery was great, the camera shots were beautiful. Even the small town seemed inviting and felt 'real' enough. Everything was absolutely stunning direction and screen writing-wise, I couldn't have asked for more or less on that regard really.

Plot

Nothing new and that's not necessarily bad. It's a love story, an unusual love story. Usually love stories' success depend on the chemistry of the two parts and in my opinion as I've already stated, that was perfect. Vulnerability meets Immortality into a beautifully made story that keeps the romantic at heart captivated.

Overall....

A GREAT movie to see with an open mind. Walk in the theater, don't expect anything and erase all of that you imagine you do or do not know about vampires and love stories. Give this movie ground to seed and grow upon without being affected by past films/books you might've read.

Twilight is a great film and I will definitely watch it again.

8/10 mostly due to the side-crew's parts being so trivial and not noticeable.

review_title: Poorly written, but the acting was... well, bad
review_text: The book I understand was pretty good. This screenplay was obviously aimed at girls aged 23 and under and is crap. Skip it. Maybe someone will do a remake in 20 years that's worthwhile. I will say the director did a fair job with the actors she was given. The male lead has that sullen "I'm actually a sensitive but complicated guy underneath all this unavailability" quality that I, and a lot of other boys, had when I was 15. But it's hard to buy from a "life form" that's supposed to be a hundred years old. I realize that it's a vampire movie and isn't supposed to be reality. That said the characters, with the exception of the female lead, aren't very well developed and leave a lot to be desired before they become capable of inspiring anything in an audience.

This film as a standalone movie is okay, nothing special just a failed excuse for a franchise starter. It's like that 'Mortal Instruments' movie or 'I Am Number Four'. They both were okay films but not executed well enough to be franchises. Twilight however apparently was worthy enough to make 3 more films out of the book series (should have just been rebooted as a show). Though the acting and dialogue in this film is cringeworthy to say the least I can say that some of the effects were not bad. That's about it though this movie didn't bore me like the rest but it also didn't entertain me either. Would have been more interesting if it wasn't centered around Bella and Edward's love story, yes I know that's the basis of the books but still it's an awkward relationship feel. The casting choices for some of these character's were also is questionable. Kirsten Stewart is the Jai Courtney of this movie, she's not a good actress.

review_title: Not As Bad As It Could Have Been
review_text:
Let me say first, while I enjoyed the books, I am not an over-obsessed fan-girl. They were entertaining, and of the four the first one was my favorite.

Going into this movie, I had some very low expectations. The trailers had disappointed me, and I was concerned about some of the actors. Thankfully, I was proved mostly wrong.

The good news first: they stayed true to the book. They didn't go all crazy or huge blockbuster, and in doing so loose the plot. I was pleasantly surprised by most of the actors, especially Robert Pattinson. I think he did a decent job of playing Edward. He pulled off the restrained parts, and was just emotional enough to be believable in the tenser parts. We didn't see much of Taylor Lautner as Jacob in this one, but the scenes he was in he did well in.

Unfortunately, where there is good there is also bad, and there is one glaring error the filmmakers made in creating this film: casting Kristen Stewart as Bella. Some of you will probably say that I'm only saying that because I wish I was Bella. I don't. Team Jacob all the way here. Anyways, she lacks the emotion required for many of the scenes, and she has the exact same look on her face for the entire film. I was very disappointed by her performance.

So, overall, a surprisingly good film, with the potential to be an 8 or 9 if you can cut Kristen Stewart out of the role of Bella. Because of her unbelievably awful performance, Twilight only earned a 6/10 from me.

review_title: Like the book I thought only the last quarter was any good
review_text:
I'm not a huge fan of the books, I ended up picking up the first one to complete a 3 for 2 offer when buying Christmas presents. The book was OK, but I think directed at younger girls than me, I'm 26. Although enjoyable enough I thought it only got interesting after the baseball game.

I think the film is pretty much the same. Both leads are quite wooden but then again the characters in the book were kind of the same, so they're actually pretty accurate. I actually liked the whole sparkling thing, in my head when reading the book it had looked really garish but I think the film handled it well. Being a 12 rating in the UK I knew it wouldn't be violent in the final fight and it didn't need to be. The film looked good and I liked that the other kids in the school were normal looking, not all model pretty people like Gossip Girl. I assume this was to make the vampires look more attractive and it worked, but I still thought it was a nice touch. The acting wasn't great but I've seen worse. The only one I thought looked wrong was Carlisle. The others were pale but to me his look was obviously lots of makeup so it just looked strange.

My main problem with it is that even though the three "bad" vampires were introduced far earlier it didn't create any suspense so I didn't think it was necessary. And then in the final showdown, the only bit of the book i would have considered remotely like action, it seemed slow and stagnant with again no build up of tension. The initial meet on the baseball field was done really well and the escape was pretty good but there was no tension built up before the fight. Even if they added in the scene from the book where Bella decides to slip away from the others it would have helped but there was nothing.

All in all not the worst film I've ever seen but certainly not the best. I didn't get an emo vibe from it but it was definitely aimed at teenage and pre teen girls. I would have given it 2 but because I'm not its target audience I bumped it up a bit.

review_title: Pretty Good Adaptation of Novel, Save Minor Details
review_text:
Unlike "Blood and Chocolate" - for which I have also reviewed - which failed to make the novel it was based after tangible and true to the storyline, "Twilight" was a pretty good adaptation of the best-selling novel it was modeled after. In my opinion, there has been no greater book-to-film adaptation than this with the exception of the "Harry Potter" films and "The Notebook." "Twilight" managed to maintain the same storyline and sequence of events; even some of the dialogue was straight from the book. The film is narrated by one of the main characters, Isabella "Bella" Swan, which gives a slight leeway into the character's thoughts, although, that which her words manage to express, her actions seem to falter doing. Kristen Stewart, who plays Bella, succeeds at one thing throughout the entire film - expressing the vulnerability that humans are equipped with and the pain of being engrossed in a forbidden love affair. Otherwise, her acting can be considered very one-note. Having read the novel myself, I knew Bella beforehand to have been a bookworm (Kristen Stewart never even picks up a book, save to do her homework), passionate (her love for Edward could have been stressed a lot more), and quite emotional. Stewart portrayed Bella the way she may have been were she only clumsy and angsty. Edward, played by Robert Pattinson, was in a word, mysterious. The character Edward Cullen is portrayed in the novels as being "The Perfect Man." He walks as though he is dancing, his voice is sweeter than the music of Debussy, and he is every bit as polite as any boy of the early 20th century. In short, he is unrealistically perfect. Pattinson brings out the brooding side of Edward Cullen - the part of him that refuses to be the monster that he is doomed to be eternally. But through all of the gloom and doom, he does a better job than Kristen Stewart does at displaying love for his significant other. He looks at Bella adoringly and protectively, while Stewart - despite the fact that she claims to be unafraid of her undead boyfriend - seems hesitant and scared of him throughout the entire film.

Ashley Greene, who played Alice Cullen, played the character straight to a T. She walked with music in her step, she was about as light and airy as a sprite, and although she was not as beautiful as I had thought, she was certainly adorable. Her partner, Jasper Hale (Jackson Rathbone) did a good job and displaying Jasper's self-restraint when trying to avoid feasting on humans, as well as with his portrayal of hostility, but the shocked look that remained on his face during almost the entire film was a little over the top.

Nikki Reed was not the woman whom I expected could pull of playing Rosalie Hale. After all, the woman is a natural (dark) brunette and is nowhere near as pale as she needed to be; and the blonde wig and powdered face that they had befitted her with took away from her natural beauty. However, reed made up from her lack of similar appearance in her performance, which fit the character quite well. Her boyfriend, Emmett Cullen was just as how I hoped he would be. Although he played the protective brother, he was still the self-confident, manly-man (or manly-vampire) that he needed to be.

Taylor Lautner did a great job playing Jacob Black. There was a comment on this website that mentioned that he was not "manly" enough; but in the first novel of the series, Jacob isn't manly at all. He is a conventional adolescent boy, which wasn't a difficult task for Lautner to pull off, seeing as how he is only sixteen-years-old.

Minor characters such as Charlie Swan, Esme Swan, Billy Black, Mike Newton, Jessica Stanley, Eric Yorkie, and Angela Weber were beautifully portrayed by the actors who played them. They were almost identical to the characters in the novel. Esme and Carlisle Cullen were also great matches in the film, even though Carlisle's hair and makeup looked ridiculous at times.

In general, the actors in the film did a fairly good job. The romance between Edward and Bella could have been portrayed through more than just a few intense glares and a make-out scene, but it is understandable that the director only had a specific time frame to work with. Whether or not you have read the books, the movie is at least worth seeing once.

review_title: You know, it's actually not that bad. The movie is actually aimed at teen girls instead of teen boys for once
review_text:
I tried watching this movie years ago when it came about and didn't bother finishing it. But in an age where every single movie is aimed at teen boys and young men - movie after movie with action, bang and crash violence, modesty thrown out the window, fast chases and massive GCI and just as terrible, if not worse, plot lines, this movie is a decent break from all that.

Like a few other reviewers I went in with very low expectations. I got half-way through the book years ago and hated it. Issue there was I was an adult trying to read a novel aimed at teen girls and a romance novel at that. Now that I got young teens myself in the house and seeing what holds their attention and what they watch on tv or choose for movies, I gotta tell you there are top watched shows today with acting and plot lines way worse than this movie (I can think of a few Doctor Who episodes of late that went down this path).

A number of the actors in this movie ended up maturing and showing their true acting chops later on down the road, especially Robert Pattison with roles such as The Dauphin in the movie The King. Water for Elephants, and the recent The Batman movie. Anna Kendrick went on to be the perfect fit for the Pitch Perfect series and in Noelle (kids movie) and the voice in Trolls. Taylor Laurent went into tv shows. Kristin Stewart's acting over the years has remained the same and she's better off modeling for Chanel.

So yeah, the acting is rough and wooden at times and the plot is laughable, but it's all good fun. I spent my time screaming at the screen that Bella is an idiot, but a teenager in love will also do some stupid things. A number of things about Bella (the character) are briefly explored in the second movie and some not fully explained in later, such as why Edward cannot read her mind.

It's a stupid teen romance movie. I mean High School Musical was terrible in terms of plot and acting, but it was a hit with the younger crowd. I had terrible romance drama's from the 90's like 'She's All That' and the 'Prince and Me' with Julie Styles that I still like and are still cult classics - I mean we ALL know they are bad, but love to watch the movie anyway.
It is an exceptional vampire movie the only reason I am not giving it 10 stars is because the books are better than the movie.

I found out about Twilight when Paramore were posting about their new songs in the film a a few months ago before the huge parade of Robert fanatics appeared.

I told my girlfriend because it's the kind of thing she'd be into and she read all the books in just under 2 weeks before the film trailers were released and was insanely hyped up about the film (not about Robert Pattinson).

As soon as the trailer was released I instantly saw what it was, just one of those really successful novels turned into a Hollywood abortion full of terrible script and dialogue and poor representation of what the fans actually read in the books, just so the production companies can make some money off the fans. Sigh ...

So I endured the horrible screams of girls (and a few lads) at every corner and waited for it to come out.

When my girlfriend forced me to see it, I literally couldn't think of a worser way to spend two hours of my life.

So heres the negatives: - Bad acting - Pattinson and Stewart (I think is how you spell it) did not work as a good combination. Her blankness ruined pretty much 3/4 of the film and Robert tried to compensate with his fairly OK acting, but it seemed to fail with her around. The scenes with just Edward were fine, but there were not many. Everyone else had minor parts, which were fairly OK, but James (the Tracker vampire) was a really bad villain and seemed to ruin the last speedy minutes he was in.

Sped up scenes - Even though the film is 2 hours long, there is a lot of scenes which just move way too fast for you to really catch everything or start to enjoy them. The first hour and a bit were really strung out though even though the scenes were really short.


Far-fetched - Some things were really far-fetched especially when Bella is bloody going off to meet James. No person would be that stupid would they? And so many of the things in it are just hard to believe during the social things (like Bella when she first meets Edward, I wont ruin it too much.


No colour and depressing - I don't know what it is, but the film is SO colourless and depressing right up until the Prom which was definitely a saviour of the movie. So don't watch this if you're suicidal or scared of grey and black.


There's a lot more things that you can figure out yourself, but thats not all.

Positives: - The musical arrangement - There was a lot of good composition during the movie that really did help the mood, but some of the songs did not totally fit. Such as Muse in the baseball scene really didn't work for me.

The "climax" - This film was so anti-climactic, but I think the climax with the fight scene between James and Edward was quite good but was over WAAAAAAAAAAY too quick. That was a highlight


I can't really think of anymore but it was definitely more negative than positive. Bella really ruined it along with her acting and unconvincing social skills.

But for Twilight fans and movie-goers not as serious as me, it's one for you.

For non-Twilight fans and serious movie-goers, give it a miss, its really not that special.

Overall : 4.5/10

AKA: "S'alright"

How do I say this without over exaggerating this? This movie was the best movie I've ever seen in my life. When Edward enters the movie the whole movie theater literally screamed out loud. This movie was everything I hoped for and more. It confirmed my belief that Edward Cullen is the ideal figure of a man. The movie had everything, humor, romance, and action. I literally fell in love with it. I will be seeing this movie again... and again... and again... and again. The only thing I regret is that Edward is fictional character and I can never have him. Oh well. I wouldn't mind settling for Robert Pattison. His acting was perfect and he embodied Edward to perfection. Kristen Stewart was a perfect Bella and I absolutely loved them on screen. My only complaint is that Alice, Rosalie,Emmett, and Jasper could have gotten more screen time. Maybe in the second movie they will. Everyone must go see it to make sure that the Twilight movies will keep being made.

OK i went in not expecting anything so i think that helped with my viewing pleasure of the movie. the bad.... 1. the movie has added things that weren't even in the book which is OK by me and not at the same time 2. some of the actors and actresses they chose to play the characters in the movie i thought were the wrong choices for them to begin with. 3. at some points i felt like i was watching a college produced film which made it seem so cheesy. the good.... 1. at some points where really good and well thought out and directed and acted which didn't spoil my mood with the film 2. they did have some scenes which came directly from the book and stayed with it. 3. there is this little bitty surprise in the movie you just have to catch it while watching. it's nothing major or anything only minor.

my rate of the whole movie is 7.5/10. it should've been made better than this way better than this all the way. i hope my review helps if any.

The first scene of Twilight is as disturbing as it is touching. A boy teenage vampire and a girl teenage vampire meet each other in a graveyard. The boy teenage vampire gives the girl teenage vampire a knowing smirk. The kind of smirk that makes the audience wonder: Are these teenage vampire lovers, perhaps? The sexual tension in the theatre at this moment was palpable.

The hunt begins! The two turn into bats; the girl becomes a pink bat (practical, yes. Realistic, also yes, but perhaps a little too gender normative for my taste). They fly high above the city, performing majestic and graceful swoops while the opening credits roll.

A middle-aged business man is going home after a long day at the office, no doubt. He's talking on his cell-phone, presumably to his wife. Little does he know that he will never see her again.

The teenage vampire bats land on the businessman's shoulders, one on each, and begin shrieking their horrifying bat-shrieks.

"Transform!" the bats shout in unison, allowing them to revert back into their human shape. Then they leap on the man, and devour him with their sharp vampire fangs. The camera is mercifully directed at the ground for this shot, so all we see are shadows and blood splattering.

Although the rest of the film is a somewhat predictable teenage vampire love romp, Director Catherine Hardwick has perfected the tried and true teenage vampire love romp formula.

4¬Ω out of 5 stars.

*SPOLIER* Some of my colleagues claim that a mere Wesley Snipes cameo would have been sufficient, and that it didn't make a lot of sense to have him kill off the entire cast in the third act. But to me it makes perfect sense. They are vampires, and so Wesley Snipes needs to kill them. I pose a rhetorical question: How else could it have possibly ended?

review_title: A Decent adaption if not great
review_text:
We all have grown up listening to vampire stories that how they only come at night and they live in coffins during daytime and the best way to keep them away is wearing a cross.So it became a tradition to depict vampires as blood thirsty an evil so when i heard from my book guy that a new book has come out it is a love story between a girl and a vampire i was surprised and wanted to try the book once just out of curiosity.\ Back at my place with this book i was simply hooked and finished the book in not my normal time and loved the book at the same time as the book did try to break many of the recorded traditions of the vampire world the concept of vegetarian vampires and superhuman powers was quite riveting.

Cut to a few months after the book came out summit entertainment came out with the movie version.Though not better than the book the movie is tightly shot and packaged.But undoubtedly the best thing is the background music which is haunting even after the movie is finished.All the book adaptations always suffer from the length of the book as compared to the length of the movie so mostly many parts of the book are edited to suite the running time of the movie.The direction is nice as the story mainly focuses on the relationship between the two main characters.Robert Pattinson portrays the dreamy eyed hero of the tale and Kirsten Stewart plays the "human".

All in All Twilight does make a good weekend watch and if you are really into the book adaptations do watch this for a original take on the vampire saga

****SPOILERS!!!! SPOILERS!!!****

Well, I thought the movie was.....AMAZING!! I cried when it began and when it ended! It was such an emotional time for me! I don't know about others, but for me it was!! The actors were perfect!! The couples all made me swoon! They worked so well together! Especially Alice and Jasper! Every time they were in the scene, I squealed! They're cafeteria entrance was amazing!!! Here are my only complaints:Taylor Lautner was not very convincing as Jacob to me. I hope he can make it work in New Moon. Lastly, they had to cram so much in 2 hours. They could have made it 2 and a half hours and no one would mind! But other than that, it was breathtaking!!

review_title: Could have been so much more
review_text:
I was left frustrated by this movie as it had all the ingredients to be something special but failed to deliver it's potential.

To be brutally honest, I think the missing ingredient was someone the likes of Joss Whedon who knows how to script teenage dialogue. As it was, some of the scenes, especially between the two lead actors were quite painful to watch.

It has many redeeming qualities that bring the film into the category of something worth watching on a rainy Sunday afternoon but I can't help but feel that it could have been so much more with the right person to bring everything together.

I was a bit sceptical when I heard that the book was being made into a movie but, honestly, I've never been more satisfied in my life!!

I love the way Catherine Hardwicke used the camera to create an abstract effect. Speaking for someone who has only just seen the movie, (It came out on the 19th in the UK)I'd have to say I have no idea what the other people who reviewed this movie watched but I think they must've taken a wrong turn and gone in to see another movie because I enjoyed it A lot- despite all the screaming fan-girls. :D I was SO not one of them.

Seriously though, I told myself not to repeatedly compare it to the book as I knew that no matter how hard they tried, they could never put on screen what I saw in my head when I read it.

I think Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart played their parts amazingly well and were very believable. I was definitely drawn in from the moment it began. Everyone in the cinema even clapped at the end, which is a rare thing for the British >.< 10/10!!

Having read the books first and then seen the film I feel I have an advantage, to be honest I always try to read books first. I have just read some of the comments and they seem to be very personal, as in personally what they think of the subject matter. May I remind them that the film is based on fictional novels and that they should try to enjoy! A little bit of myth, fiction, history and contemporary life is a perfect ingredient, especially when well written. Some viewers do not seem to realise that a novel cannot be made into a film, all 300 odd pages that is, unless they want to spend several days in the cinema. Most adverse remarks from viewers make me think they are not actually watching and/or listening but just seeing. I love films and books, and we all have our own personal taste. Not good or bad just what we like.

review_title: Excellent translation from book to film...
review_text:
Walking into the theater was one of the scariest moments for me. Seeing how the Harry Potter movies have developed and apparently deviated from the book (according to my furious father), I was so afraid that this was just going to be some fluffy teenage angst movie with the only similarities to the book that inspired it being the title slapped on it and characters with similar names to the characters in the books...

And luckily, that wasn't the case. Catherine Hardwicke and Melissa Rosenberg did an excellent job of translating the essence of the first book in the Twilight saga from book to film. Without deviating from the book too much (at least not noticeably enough), they captured visually what Stephenie Meyer captured through written word.

I thought both Kristen Stewart (Bella) and Rob Pattinson (Edward) did great jobs at portraying not only their characters, but the intensely emotional relationship between the 'star-cross'd' lovers. All the supporting cast members, the Cullens and Bella's school friends, were great; in character and spot-on every time. I was especially impressed with Jasper (Jackson Rathbone)'s performance, portraying the restraint and struggle without making it seem overdone and over the top.

My favorite scene was the baseball scene. It was EXACTLY how I pictured it while I read the book. Even better, was the energy of the whole scene was hyped up with Muse's "Supermassive Black Hole" playing in the background...

What I didn't expect was how hilarious the entire movie ended up being! In a (negative) review of Twilight I read in my newspaper, it said that "the witty banter between Edward and Bella about their respective immortality and humanity is completely lost and all that's left is a slog of teenage angst." HOW WRONG THEY WERE! Kristen Stewart and Rob Pattinson deliver the funny and awkward lines with perfect timing... "Edward/Rob: I just told you that I read minds, and you think there's something wrong with *you*?!?" I thought it was hilarious.

And who could forget Charlie (Billy Burke), sweet, protective, Charlie?! From the first time you see him driving Bella home from the airport, awkwardly and stealthily glancing at her, looking as if he's wondering if he should say something or just stay silent, the adorable connection between "Charlie" and daughter is made. One of the best scenes is when Bella comes out to Charlie about her and Edward "dating" and the look on his face is priceless! "Bella/Kristen: I'm going on a date with Edward Cullen. Charlie/Billy: I thought that you weren't interested in any boys in town... Bella/Kristen: *pause* Well... Edward doesn't technically live in town. Charlie/Billy: *silent and continues to clean shot gun* Bella/Kristen: And... he's here now to formally introduce himself. Charlie/Billy: Alright... *snaps shotgun shut and cocks it* Bring him in."

Priceless. Just... priceless.

The only reason I took 1 star off of my review is because of the special effects... they weren't "cheesy" like everyone complains, but the could've been a little better, maybe with more funding. This was a surprisingly low-budget movie. Hopefully when they're filming the second movie for "New Moon" they'll bust out the big special effects for the 'werewolves' transformations, considering Stephenie Meyer describes it as a "pop."

This movie and all of the movies after it is like a gigantic slide show. There are no real details to care about unless you read the books. All of the things that are talked about about this movie, such as overly popular Bella, a 100 year old virgin, a cheesy teen romance...The book is in the point of view of a young teenage girl that discovers that her world is crawling with the creatures and legends that no one thought existed. Twilight the book is excellent because of its syntax, diction, and allusion. (A person would not appreciate this book if they hate lovey dovey romances, teenage moods, and vampires that are into talking not biting or if they are male) Knowing the story, this movie is a very bad interpretation. This movie translated a smart, responsible, and an often selfish girl into a mindless emo chick. The vampires are fairy like and look just fail in the movie. (I mean why would you make a supposedly terrifying male vampire sparkle and make sparkle noises!) The book makes Edward very alluring and he actually resembles a Greek statue. It may sound far fetched, but the vampires in the books were a lot more terrifying than the ones in the movies. To put this in another way: Twilight the book is like a tub of ice cream and the movie is like one single dippin dot.

review_title: One of the better vampire flicks....
review_text:
I got interested in Twilight after I saw a trailer for it that came on before Death Race Started....At least I think it was Death Race. It wasn't until after I actually saw the film that I found out girls like it, Whatever I think it's awesome. many films have tried to show vampires live in the normal world but usually they never get past the Bram Stoker vampire. This actually had a good reason they live such odd lives.

I like the idea of a vampire romance, the idea that someone willingly chooses to become the undead, that someone falls so in love with another that they would follow the person into hell just to be with them.... If that's not love I don't know what is.....

The plot I thought was good, the action when it came up was quick and there really wasn't much blood. The strongest point of the film is the characters.... Once introduced you instantly knew who was good and who wasn't and there was those few that you weren't quite so sure of until they showed you who they were under fire.

The other thing I liked about this film was it's location, Washington State. I was there when I was a kid but vaguely remember it, I remember it rained a lot, I remember it was very green with trees but not much else so it was nice seeing Washington in a film.

I'll admit that when I first heard about the movie, I was sceptical. How could they make something that was so wonderful on so many levels into a two hour long movie?

But then I saw the trailers, and (in the words of Mr Darcy, whom Stephenie Meyer cites as one of her influences for Edward) they 'caused me to hope as I'd scarce dared hope before.' For me, within the first few seconds Kristen Stewart had stopped being Kristen Stewart. She had unconditionally and irrevocably become Isabella Swan - dreamer, loner.

The incredibly talented cast brought the book to life in ways I'd never expected. Additions to the script simply added to the overall vibe of brilliance that Twilight simply has.

And for all those who are freaking out because the movie doesn't follow the book to the letter - do you really want to sit there and watch three hours of Bella lying in bed being emo over Edward? Thought not.

Having read the books - which are really good - I am embarrassed by the joke that is this franchise. Unless you've read the books you'll have no idea what's going on cos there is hardly any dialogue

Really really poor.

review_title: Nice movie, but a bit overrated
review_text:
I went to watch Twilight with my friends, and I was excited to see it from all the good hype, the dark theme and the aspiring trailer. And guess what, I wasn't disappointed. As I am the critic between my friends, they went by my opinion and some of them REALLY liked it as some other thought of it as "Yeah, it was good."

For me, Twilight was good, but not as great as people overrated it. Teens used to overrate things like High School Musical and its sequels, which I find silly from my side, mainly because of their lightweight storyline and constant teen-pop, but also rated well Hannah Montana, the nice show with not-bad pop-rock and good comedy and plot. I was confused whether to watch Twilight or not at first, but when I saw the trailer and also continued to know the plot spoiler from here, I had to watch it. It was fun.

Pros and Cons:

PROS:-

-The dark theme is well done, and Pattinson is good for Edward's role.

-The cheesiness is much cut out, unlike Disney movies, and the characters do actually suite what teens are today (e.g. Eric)

-Effects, semi-intense scenes, soundtrack and emotions are well presented and well done.

-The relationship is more realistic than in other teen movies, and is truly deep.

CONS:-

-The entrance of the movie was partly bad and confusing. For people who did not read the book, it did confuse a bit. Thanks God I understood what was happening because I read a synopsis earlier.

-The chase of Bella Swan was given good timing, but is a bit disappointing for who saw the trailer. It is not given enough time to make it a good movie chase, but it is not that bad.

-If you can wait for a DVD, it's better if you want quiet watching. The hype of teens completely ruins the movie with constant laserpen pointing, girly screams, fights, booting and other mess. I hate hyped movies, especially when they're good to watch but not in theaters.

To be or not to be, to watch or not to watch?

TO WATCH OR NOT TO WATCH

-Watch if you like dark themes, thrillers, romance, drama, action, vampires, dark but not horror, semi-horror, serious teen movies.

-Don't watch if you like constant action, constant effects, or hate corny-joke movies, dark movies and instant-relation movies.

-----

That makes it up for me and you all out there. I tried to be as fair as I could, and that's what I came up with. :)

review_title: ? To be honest.....it's just about a girl who falls in love a SPARKLY period sucker!
review_text:
If there were to be a 0 out of 10, I would choose that! First of all, there was a plot.....wait...no there wasn't! It was simply just about a girl who goes to Forks, and she falls in love with a vampire. Then her sister gets picked to fight to the death- oh wait.....no....that's the Hunger Games! Oh right! She goes to Hogwarts, a school for wizards-.....wait....NO! It is LITERALLY about a girl who falls in love with a vampire!

What about the actors? Kristen Stewart was horrid. All she could do was stare at the dead thing's eyes and.......sigh :( she would sigh when she wants a dramatic pause. But it wasn't dramatic! I was a bit proud of Robert though, he did alright.

So all the so called Twi-hards out there, go fan-girl Hunger Games or Harry Potter instead of this!

I finally decided to watch twilight because the entire franchise is on netflix, and honestly i was pleasantly surprised. I expected this movie to be downright horrible, but it was actually decent. There are definitely cringeworthy moments (the way edward stares at bella at the beginning of the movie, for example), but overall it was a lot better than i anticipated.

The script was painfully awkward as was the acting. Kristen Stewart's acting was about as wooden as it could get. Robert Pattinson was expressionless in most of his scenes. Whenever the Cullens were in a scene they were always paired off which seemed so unnatural (even for vampires). The only actor I found remotely acceptable was Billy Burke who offered some comic relief and delivered his lines naturally.

The special effects were abysmal and reminded me of that hilariously bad scene in the original 1978 Superman movie where Clark Kent was running beside the train. Why on earth did they skimp on the special effects? Oh, god, and then there was that insane baseball game! Why? Why was it included at all? Far too much cringe going on in every scene to make this movie enjoyable.

I couldn't understand the yellow hair either. Why did a couple of the Cullen's hair colour look like a really bad home dye job? To top it off, the musical score was also woeful.

This is a very, very poor film. I feel sorry for the actors in it. I'm glad Anna Kendrick and Michael Sheen have survived this abominable series and redeemed their acting careers.

I'm a huge book-to-movie skeptic. I always expect them to be awful. But I saw Twilight and it followed the story fairly well - there were a few different things, of course, but it wasn't enough to make me think, "No, it didn't go like that!" The characters were good, and the actors portraying them did a good job for the most part. There were, of course, down points (Kristen Stewart's sputtering in the hospital bed and in the hallway), but overall I think that the movie followed the book well and delivered a beautiful love story. Some parts were a bit silly ("Hold on tight, spider monkey!"), but it appeals to the masses of 14-year-old girls who all went to see Robert Pattinson as Edward :) and I must say, he IS gorgeous!

review_title: An enjoyable film and great introduction to the books
review_text:
Although I'm 46, I wanted to see this film and find out what all the hype was about. I thoroughly enjoyed it, especially Robert Pattinson's role as Edward Cullen. Kirsten Stewart I found rather flat, but she did have great chemistry with Pattinson.

What I didn't know, though, is how it really only picks the bones of a much deeper book, a book that it would really be impossible to religiously transfer to screen. After seeing the film I sat down and read all 4 books in about 3 days, thoroughly enjoying the much fuller detail and characterisation, which made me realise how little of the story could be put onto the screen, the books being so much inside the characters heads instead of spoken (especially Twilight).

So, it's an enjoyable film and a nice interpretation, but if by some chance you haven't read the books, do so as they are much more meaty and satisfying.

I watched this film just after reading the books (four books in four days, nonstop) so all the details were very fresh in my head. And I definitely liked the film but something in it disturbed me, I tried to figure out what exactly it was but couldn't. So I watched it again trying not to get engrossed in it; it was not easy but I did it. This is what I got: I've watched a lot of films - book's adaptations- and understood that it's almost impossible to make a perfect script for a 2-hour movie from a several hundred page book. "Twilight" film script is far from perfect but frankly speaking I didn't expect it to be perfect. So that definitely wasn't the reason of my annoyance.

I like the whole cast, especially the Cullens family: the protective father of the family Dr.Carlisle, the loving mother Esme, beautiful and furious Rosalie (though I pictured her a little different when reading the book), strong and funny Emmett (more funny in the book ), a little too restrained among humans Jasper, charming Alice and Edward, of course. If Edward had been cast wrong it would've ruined the film. So many thanks to Catherine Hardwicke - as I know there were a lot of actors in the queue for Edward - for her patience and right choice. And kudos to Robert Pattinson for his Edward! I forgot that that was Robert Pattinson playing Edward after a few seconds of his first appearance on screen. I didn't see Robert, I saw Edward with all his emotions - from embarrassment and hunger for Bella's blood to his passion and tenderness for her- on his face. He is really a good actor; it seems he isn't acting , he is living his character's life.

I like the music very much, it creates proper mood from the first notes up to the end.

But it was not the bright lipstick or the abrupt boundary between the snow-white face and the normal neck of Edward or Carlisle that disturbed me. So what? And suddenly I realized that it was Kristen Stewart's Bella. It WAS NOT Bella from the book. Kristen performed three emotions: boredom, irritation and total absence of any emotions with her mouth open all the time. Where is Bella's love for Edward? I didn't see a single moment when she was almost fainting with love hearing his voice or looking at his eyes. Kristen's Bella is strong (it seemed that it was not her who needed help in the sequence with four scoundrels but them - her voice was absolutely confident and she already started to punch them), she is not awkward (as in the book), always demanding something from Edward, with strange twitch of her face and sounds from her throat (which reminded me of some of her public interviews). So I saw Kristen, not Bella.
