This review took me around 15 minutes but I feel like I have just claimed a bit of my life back by writing it.

review_title: I recommend everyone to watch this great movie
review_text: I give it a 5 because I loved this movie when I was a teenager. This movie is a love story of a very socially awkward girl with another very socially awkward boy who happens to be a vampire, with beautiful shots and music. Keep that in mind while watching it. A lot of people don't like the movie because they expect the teenage protagonist to behave in a certain way, to be a role model, when in fact this is not at all necessary. There's nothing wrong with being quiet, awkward, unenthusiastic, and somber. There is nothing wrong with enjoying this film just because of the short dialogues, the eye contact, and the beautiful aesthetic atmosphere in which the characters are involved. Don't expect this movie to be a romantic comedy with laughs and fun just because it is a movie for teenagers.

review_title: The Worst Movie I've Ever Seen
review_text:
I can honestly say there are not words to describe how terrible this movie really was, and I'm crushed. I loved the books and was so hopeful going in, but after coming out I felt I needed to go home and watch a decent movie to get the awkwardness out of my head. Really, it wasn't the actors' faults. They did their best with what they were given, but with the cheesy script, terrible direction (I think this director should consider combining forces with Uwe Boll), sub par make-up and costuming, and more close ups than a covergirl commercial there was no way that the cast could salvage the film.

If you're considering going to see this movie before it leaves theaters (which will hopefully be soon), you should definitely see a matin√©e. And, really, just save the money and rent it when it comes out. I'm sure that irregardless of how terrible this movie is they will still continue the adaptations, because they're going to make money. I just hope that some of that money will go into hiring more experienced and qualified staff next time.

Why so low? Well, firstly, the narration was very very deadpan. Bella wasn't someone who emoted very well. Her acting seemed very awkward. All the acting seemed very awkward. To me, it seemed like the director said, "Ok. You're playing Bella and you, you're playing Edward. There's some tension. Some vampire creepy secrecy going on. Now, be awkward. That's right. Now, stutter. Pause. Say 'Um' and collect your thoughts a lot. More awkward... no just a little bit more awkward. Now fidget. You can fidget with your jacket, with your jeans, with your bag, with your hair... just fidget, and be sure to do it a lot... awkwardly. Edward... force your chuckles. And when I mean force, I mean that your chuckles are superglue in a container that has been sealed for months and the last person to use this container of superglue was your clumsy little brother who left lint on the nozzle as well as excess glue which dried and you have to squeeze out your chuckles, smiles, and lines from that. DIG OUT THOSE CHUCKLES AND EMOTIONS BOY!" After that, it seemed odd that Bella was welcomed so WELL into the new school. I can see how people from a small town might be interested in this prized jewel known as the new girl, since I'm from one myself, but you had to be too cool for school to get in with everyone, considering everyone is supposed to be friends or close in a small town... at least mine was. The warm and continuously warm welcome, if not blazing hot welcome, seemed unrealistic to me.

The glistening vampire thing was handled better than I was expecting. People who weren't fans of the book or movie would giggle and laugh and call it ridiculous.

The rest of the vampire lore was interesting in that it was venom and not a disease, like most books or movies use these days. I also really liked the history of the local Native American tribe and the Cullens. It made a lot of sense and was very cool.

However, a lot of the time I was squirming in my seat due to the whole awkward nature of the film. All the dialogue seemed like a huge struggle for the actors to get out. The movements and actions were awkward. I can't use the word "awkward" enough, eh? Bella's friends, with exception to the cool Asian guy, made me embarrassed, because I often get embarrassed for characters on screen for some reason. The "you're a powerful woman" delivered in such a deadpan voice made me facepalm.

I didn't like that all Bella could say was "I don't care" when Edward was revealing what he was. It was repetitive and didn't make it look like Bella had much coherent thought behind anything she was saying.

Things started to pick up at the baseball game, which I enjoyed more than I thought I would. Acting became more believable, no more awkward junk, and certainly a threatening feel to it. Loved the whole fighting vampire scene and Bella's acting was great as she was writhing on the floor. I liked the video editing and transitions when Edward needed to force himself away.

However, I don't feel that I needed to wait an hour and a half for something to happen that I was interested in.

And, to be honest, I was more interested in the werewolves than the vampires... and they didn't even show up. I wish that they had more bits with Alice. She's claimed to be "odd" or "weird" and I wanted to see if she was a character that I could latch onto, since I really like characters like that... but there were hardly any scenes with her.

Like the title of the thread says, I wasn't all that impressed.

OK, where do i begin.. i remember watching the trailer for this movie on TV. and i though, cool, looks like a good action/thriller/or something. as probably many other poor souls out there, who had to endure what i endured. i remember sitting in the theater and thinking to my self after 20min "ok, now the action better start" after 30min i realized "ok, this is as good as it gets". I'v never been this embarrassed watching a movie. i tried to hide my face walking out of the cinema, cause to call this movie a chick-flick is quite the understatement. 122min of vampire/love psycho babble.

PS: never see this movie!

review_title: You like it or you don't
review_text:
I think the people who rate this low are the people who thinks the movie misses a lot from the book or the one who thinks that this movie just sucks with all the vampires etc. and maybe the people who just doesn't like this kind of movie and maybe sees it a bit cheesy. I don't know! But I do know that I love this movie, and my brother isn't the kind of person who likes these kinds of movies, he thinks Twilight, New Moon is pretty cool! I think I like this one, Twilight, the most because it is much about high-school and Bella not knowing Edward is a vampire. Of course the movie isn't all the same as in the book. There are more details and in that way it feels like you're Bella but I think the movie did great! I saw the movie first so I have nothing to say like "They ruined how I pictured Edward and everyone!!" etc. I think all the actors are doing great!

This is definitely a movie everyone should watch. If you love this movie then you have something too look forward; the upcoming movies and also the books!

review_title: I thought it was good...why so harsh?
review_text:
The books were way better.But Twilight did capture the main points of the book.It was very good compared to what they had to work with.In some points it did drag on, and lots of things weren't there at all.But I thought it was good.Don't listen to haters, please.Because all they want to do is play critic-of-the-year and decide for you what's good and what's not.

Twilight, all in all, wasn't bad.It wasn't amazing, either.But it was a decent movie to watch.I really enjoyed it, almost as much as I enjoyed the book.Haters don't like it because of the sparkling.It's imagination, people.There is no actual definition of what a vampire looks like.So there is no actual description of what they should be.

The acting...could have been better.But it was believable.And if you don't like this movie, then don't trash the book.The books are better.And who says Stephenie Meyer can't write?I'm sure she can.Because I found all of the books hard to put down.And, she got them published, so it couldn't be as bad as you think.

It is also not gay.Whoever says it's gay obviously needs a dictionary in front of them to look up the meaning of the word "gay".Gay either means happy or attracted to the same sex.There are no gays/lesbians in the movie, and I don't find anything happy about it, so therefore it is not gay.By any means.People really need to lighten up.A lot.Because it is a good movie.But I would recommend this.

review_title: Book is better but movie is still good
review_text:
I did make the mistake of reading the book first. I swore to myself if I knew a book was being made into a movie I would wait for the movie, especially after the Harry Potter catastrophe. I spent every single move to busy going, "Yes, I remember that part." "Yea it happened like that." "That's not how I pictured it looking like." And so on and so forth. That was how I spent the first viewing of Twilight. The movie, to me seemed to pass by really fast. I was able to pick up on a lot of underlying sub-plots but that was again because I had read the book.

I was lucky enough to view it a second time with someone who had not read the book. So at the end I asked her what she thought. She felt the story and plot were great; there were a few things she didn't understand, like Alice's whole vision things. I did explain a few concepts behind the visions and she said it help a little to understand some parts of the movie. It wasn't that the movie skipped over it, it was just explained to fast and she missed it. She did love the chemistry between Bella and Edward. It kind of reminded her of Romeo and Juliet. For those who have read ALL the books they understand why that comparison is very entertaining.

So unlike other good books that are turned into movies I felt that this one was able to hold it's own without someone having to read the book, you just need to go see it a second time, which I feel it worth the money.

I became a fan of the books late in the game. I got them ALL in August (2008) and read them all within 5 days. Since that time I have read them each about 5 times. I am also reading them allowed and recording them for my husband who HATES to read (and I ain't spending $30 a pop on the CD's). So I have the books just about memorized. I heard someone mention there isn't a plot, well there is...to see if true love can SURVIVE. Now I did not have HIGH expectations because I know what I saw in my head could in no way be done perfectly in reality so I went in HOPING that it would at least be good. I was greeted with a VERY good portrayal of what I read. Of course MANY things were left out or changed...I mean how many girls loved the blood typing...not in the movie, and how many liked the jacket being left behind and she gets to wear his and SMELL him...also not in it. OK the beginning was FAST, I know this was done to get to the meat and potatoes of the story so I forgive them for that. But there were three things that I was a bit stubborn on 1.) the kisses 2.)Baseball 3.)Sparkle Edward. So I can say I was NOT disappointed. SPOILER possibly (depends on how you look at it)** The kiss is described as chaste in the books because of his fear of cutting her. A lot of hype on the internet about it being more "frenchy"...it wasn't, it was the perfect combination of chaste and passionate!!! Baseball WOW~!!! They did such a good job that I wanted more the only flaw I found was when the Cullens converge to protect Bella...they all move like Apes and are hissing and it looks a little weak, did not have the "power" effect that is supposed to be there. But I like the vortex shot, what I mean is the last time Rosalie bats, when she swings, she does it SO HARD that the swoosh creates an air vortex that spins Esme's hair around and back into her face...it made the shot real. SPARKLE: OME! I dreaded this because I truly did not think they would be able to do it. But they succeeded...yes, it is a little cheesy but I think it is cheesy because there are these "ting ting" sound effects to his glisten...what was that about. I never imagined a sound when he shimmered...so that was a little weird.

Okay, the second time I went I took my cousin who has NOT read the books. When a movie is made from a book they usually are trying to tell the story so that ANYONE can watch and follow but they messed up in a few spots here. In the beginning when Edward sees Bella in the cafeteria and he is looking at her with puzzlement...we readers know it is because he cannot hear her thoughts, but my cousin was like "What the?" Then in Biology when she walks in and he scent is blown towards him, he grabs his nose and convulses like he might be sick. My cousin was like "Okay, he falls for her but she makes him sick?? WHAT?" So I had to explain to him what was happening. Other than those items I think people can follow it and ENJOY it. My husband LOVED it, he was the reason we went back a second time. My cousin enjoyed it too. So two guys liked it and so did I!!

**I couldn't understand why Jaspers gift was not explained, it seemed like Edward began to tell Bella but just stopped with Alice. I really liked the wolf references in the film to prep for the next one and of course the ending was very smart!!!

I recommend this movie to everyone, it is the perfect mix of funny, sweet, angry, scared, sad and romantic!!

review_title: I've seen the movie and read the books.
review_text:
I am a very hard critic when it comes to making books into movies. I hated all but the third HP movie, as far as I'm concerned they are mostly disasters.

Twilight on the other hand did a fair job of retelling the story on film. There was one notion I felt needed to be there, the irony of the argument between Bella and Edward about her not ever having to give her life for him thereby proving her love vs. her actually choosing to go to James to save Edward. That conversation was rather nebulous in the book as well so I can see why it was left out or over looked.

I wish that directors would read the books as well as the screenplays so they could make adjustments rather that relying on studio execs to approve the screenplay and work from it exclusively, I think this is the point of problem in turning books into movies.

Edward and Bella are beautifully portrayed and the movie does move along and the cinematography just makes you want to cry. And the boy playing Jacob Black..HOT HOT HOT.

Over all its a decent evening with hubby and btw, my husband is harder than I am to please when it comes to this kind of movie making and he enjoyed himself too.

I was initially excited for this movie. I knew they were adapting it for screen weeks before they had even picked actors. Then, I saw it. Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson. Kristen gives a terrible performance. She has no emotion, is completely mono-tone, stutters, and she doesn't even look like she wants to be there. Robert Pattinson just tries too hard. And those close-ups! If you look, you can see the HUGE amount of make-up they put on his face, and look even closer and you can see his contacts. The only actor's performance I did like was Taylor Lautner, and he's only in the movie for about 10 minutes tops. And of course, you gotta give the credit for this movie going down the toilet to...the director! Catherine Hardwicke is NOT, I repeat, NOT a good director. Her style is absurd. Her shots are short and move so fast it confuses you to the point that you have to rewind about 10 minutes back and put it into slow motion just so that you can see what you're SUPPOSED to see the first time around. And don't even bother to compare it to the books. The books are passionate, and show how emotionally attached Bella and Edward are. The movie just pushes that all aside and throws in a scenes of them making out - you can even see tongue. I honestly just can't wait until they remake this in about 50 years. If I'm still alive, I'll gladly go see it in hope that they topped this one, which won't be too hard to do.

the most boring film i have seen in a long time. i am a big fan of vampire movies but this one.......... no way.

i sat there throughout the whole film wandering when something was going to happen.

every time i did think a good bit was coming up i was let down.

also bad acting from Kristen Stewart although i'm not sure its so much her acting as she is just dull and boring i was very disappointed in this film and it wasn't worth watching i certainly wont be running out to the shops to buy this one.

another disappointing film with Kristen Stewart acting

review_title: Twilight ¬ñ Watch it twice then decide.
review_text: I have seen Twilight twice now and the first time I saw it, all I did was criticized it. Did not enjoy it one bit and thought it should have stayed true to the story. However when my friends dragged me along to see it again, I enjoyed it this time. Go into the cinema with an open mind is my advice. Don't think it will be anything like the book. Films are meant to be quick. Harry Potter is not true to the book however everyone enjoyed it. The same needs to be seen with Twilight. The only thing that annoyed me the most about Twilight was the directing and camera directing. Many of the close ups were not needed, yes this was a romantic film but there is a line to be drawn. Catherine Hardwicke I believe is not a great director and someone else should have directed the film to make the characters stronger. I felt they were missing something on screen. If you have read the book and did not like it the first time because you expected much more, go see it again. I'm glad I did. I accepted it for what it was much more the second time.

I have read all of the twilight books and was so excited to see the movie I knew I would love it I loved all the books. I went on Friday when it came out, to tell you the truth I was not disappointed BUT, I was comparing the movie to the book the entire time I was watching it. I had to go see it again on Sunday. I'm so glad I did I just sat their and really enjoyed it. I do understand they had to compact a 500 page book into a 89 minute movie and I think they really did a good job with it,even though they left out a lot of jokes between Bella and Edward but the chemistry they had between each other was GREAT. The baseball game was so awesome it made me want to become a vampire just to play like that, I hate sports, I am very bad at them I failed gym in high school. I'm also happy with the part when she was getting the information out of Jacob at the beach, in the book he actually said ware wolves and vampires in the movie he only said wolves and pale faces, it was nice that she had to figure it out on her own...All in all i LOVED it and i hope they make the other 3 books into movies!!!!

I don't get why people thought it was a disappointment? I loved it. and I just gotta say that when I first saw the movie, I had never heard of Stephanie Meyer's novels. and when I got out of the cinema, I was thinking: "I wanna see it again. NOW." Seriously, you can't compare the movie with the book! OF COURSE it's not the same, no movie is exactly the same as the book, just look at Harry Potter. I think Twilight is a great movie ( I LOVE the chemistry between Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart, Robert Pattinson is so saucy XD) after I watched the movie, I wanted to read the books, and so I did, and I LOVE THEM ! the books are genius! of course I like the books more, but you can't do anything else but love the movie too. and the actors. I can't wait for New Moon!

all in all, Twilight = GREAT MOVIE!!

It seems the entire population of Twilight viewers have either an unhealthy obsession , or have chosen to reject it and start anti-Twilight discussions. But really, Twilight is not worthy of either of those things.

Twilight is a decent, tolerable film, however, whatever charm the book possessed that made it so interesting has been lost during the making of this film. The biggest problem with Twilight is the character, Bella. The initial character had about as much emotional depth as a teaspoon; she was barely even a character, more so a mate created to love Edward. Nevertheless, with her narration in the books, we are forced to relate to her to a certain extent. Whatever personality she may have had was completely pulverized by Kirsten Stewart. Bella is so unenthusiastic and uninteresting, we have to wonder if she even has a brain, or why her classmates want so badly to be her friend. She expresses very little emotion, and comes across and as careless and conceited. Her lack of character provides an opportunity for the infatuated girl audiences to see themselves as Bella to satisfy their fantasies of having the 'prefect man' (Edward).

Robert Pattinson was a likable Edward. He took his own turn with the role, and came out with a quirky, almost awkward character. Despite some of his painfully cheesy lines, he did well. However, the couple's supposed "love" for each other is shallow, and not quite believable.

There are a few touching moments between Bella and her father, and a few laughable moments as well. And as far as the directing goes, the film was beautifully shot. All of this combined with some cheesy dialog an poor special effects creates a somewhat enjoyable, yet forgettable, mediocre film.

review_title: Really depends on your own personal aesthetic desires.
review_text:
This is by far my favorite movie of the series, and one of my favorite movies of all time. The story line is just OK for me. I will admit, there are cringe moments. I do enjoy a love story, the idea of immortality, infinite beauty and wealth...yes. It isn't profound to me, though. But the cinematography and beautiful soundtrack tap into a part of my soul that always needed a physical representation, and Twilight is it. Your own aesthetic desires will determine if you enjoy this film. For me, Twilight taps into that part of my soul that lives for: dreary days, heavy rain, stormy nights, intensely green forests, scenic views, melancholy, mystery, hauntingly beautiful music. Twilight is my favorite time of day because colors are muted into jewel tones and there is this fleeting sense of magic and mystery. I feel like this movie makes those feelings tangible.

The music brings to feelings to life. Bella's Lullaby is so incredible to my ears. I listen to it frequently. I just cannot express enough my desire to jump into this movie and live in it. I am so grateful this movie was created.

I fully understand the negative reviews this series receives, but I personally believe it is the other films (that really aren't that impressive to me) that drag down this first film.

review_title: Girls will love it, Guys not so much
review_text:
I was dragged along to this horrendous movie with a group of friends, a lot of them female and they thought oh yeah Twilight will be awesome. It wasn't, this is one of the single most boring movie I have ever sat through.

You would think because there are vampires that there would be some promise but no not really, the first part of the movie is so horribly boring, like nothing happens at all they just talk about stupid stuff for ages, nobody cares if this kid wants to ask you to prom (allthough she is pretty hot).

There are two good parts though, the Baseball scene is pretty epic. Like it's super awesome and it should've gone longer maybe then it wouldn't have been so boring and the fight scene was pretty good with Edward (the main guy that looks stoned) fighting James (the bad guy) but it was way too short.

Anyway the girls I was with really liked it for some reason, so ladies this is one for you defiantly, guys not so much.

review_title: A Terrible movie saga, don't even waste your time looking at it. It can be summed up as a "brainless cash grab".
review_text:
The story make no sense and keep contradicting itself.

The main character is 1 dimensional and has no character development.

The relationship between the characters is psychologically manipulative. If you want your daughters to date horrible men that would use and manipulate them then go ahead and tell them to watch this rubbish.

This saga even promote "romantic relationship" between a full a grown adult and a baby so if you are a paedophile then you might like this I guess.

In summary this movie saga is an insult to our intelligence and should not have been even existed in the first place.

review_title: So your telling me Twilight gets less stars than "Deuce Bigalow; Male Gigolo"
review_text:
All of the haters and wannabe critics love to make fun of and tell you that this movie is a 4/10 and that they "never even read the books cause they aren't a 16 year old girl". Well as someone who was a 16 year old girl who read Twilight in book form and then enjoyed the movie years later... they did a great job on this movie! Whilst yes a little cheesy (some things don't always translate well from book form in most film adaptions). The acting was exactly perfect for the characters that Stephanie Meyers wrote. So even if they weren't the worlds best actors they did a great job in the role they were given. You try to be a hunger crazed teenage vampire who is actually 100's of years old, just met your soulmate who inadvertently happens to be your biggest weakness all the while ignoring your base instincts to kill. It's gotta be a tough gig.

The cinematography of Twilight is beautiful and not just because of the scenery. Someone actually spent some love and care making this movie. They worked hard to respect the book and respect the atmosphere and feelings that it's meant to portray. This movie wasn't made for film critics or indie movie watchers or men or women who thought it was a joke even before they started it. It was made for the people who made it popular in the first place. The feelings this movie invokes are stronger than it's 5.3 rating. Twilight deserves better.
Wow great movie. my second favourite movie number 1 is endgame. that part where he killed Murray really got me. this says a lot about our society
This movie is about a girl and a vampire Loving story,they don't care about their difference,become more and more loveing,finally they become a double vampires

review_title: Robert Pattinson is Edward; weak storyline
review_text:
I have read the books.

I think Robert Pattinson is an excellent Edward Cullen.

I do agree with most people who are disappointed by the storyline. It seemed like Bella went from being confused about Edwards dislike for her to being totally in love with him - that quickly. The book draws you into more of the development about why these two were so drawn to each other and the movie definitely lacks that.

I loved, loved, LOVED Robert Pattinson as Edward Cullen - he absolutely did it for me. Something about they way he phrased things and delivered his lines made me absolutely feel like that is what Edward would say and that is EXACTLY how Edward would say it.

Bella was less convincing, but I cannot blame Kristen Stewart; she was probably handed a bum and unconvincing story line that did not help create the being that is Bella Swan.

I thoroughly enjoyed the baseball scene, Alice was truly Alice for me, Rosalie was just as convincing. Jasper seemed very constipated and did nothing for me; neither did Emmett. Esme was Esme for me. I think the casting was pretty good; I just wish the storyline had been better.

Jacob was okay; there was more of a tortured relationship between Bella and Jasper that I would have preferred to see on the screen.

I have to give it a low score though because it just didn't translate that well for me to the big screen and I can only hope they do much better with the sequels.

review_title: This is for all you reviewers who are hating this film so much. I don't get why y'all hating it so much, pls stop with hate guys
review_text:
Ok guys seriously, I've been reading these reviews and come on, the movies were NOT THAT BAD! Seriously people, try to think about all the people, all the actors, all the special effects required to make the film, and the film was actually rather good in my opinion

BELLA : I see a lot of you arguing that Kristen had no expression, people, I just read the book like a few weeks ago and let me just tell you, that's what Bella is like, in my opinion Kristen played Bella rather well, Bella acts plain, bland and stumbles with her words, so get. Over. It.

EDWARD : yes yes, we were all lovey dovey over Edward because of handsome Robert but hey, he played Edward seriously well, the expressions the "old-school" English the way he played Edward was so good I truly fell in love

THE PLOT : ok seriously, all of you who rated this film, don't you get it! No film is ever EVER gonna be perfect to the books, and I get that, I've been mad at plenty of movies for that, but that does not mean you can shed so much hate on it, I'm a person who absolutely adored this fandom and Meyer's writing, and this film was actually rather good, given the budget, but the casting was great and they did the best they could, so put yourself in the directors place and then think, could you really have done it better? Before you write a review yeah?

This movie isn't so bad but I find something lacking. I didn't get bored watching the movie but I am not completely satisfied when it's over. I find the special effects pretty dull and it's just like watching a TV episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer or Angel. The story is very simple really.. it's about a girl who falls in love with a vampire and the vampire in turn must resist eating her. There's nothing spectacular about the movie, it's plain old story telling. I'm pretty sure the teenage girls would love this movie because of the love story in it but it's definitely just another fairy tale. The actors are decent in this movie, for sure they're not getting an Academy for this but they played it fair.

review_title: Worth watching, despite some painful scenes
review_text:
I'm not too familiar with Gothic and emo movies in general, but suppose you can count this as one of them.

I liked the slightly dark atmosphere and the thought on death and life. Also i liked the visual style of the pictures, like short before a thunderstorm is coming up, but nearly through the whole movie. Perhaps a little like in "Sleepy Hollow". There were some hard to watch sequences, where all there is is shallow acting and it's all about 'look how cute our protagonist is!', which was a little unnerving for me as a guy, but: There was a line that was not quite crossed, if you get my drift.

So all in all an entertaining movie, if you just want action you probably should see something else.

6/10

While I agree that this isn't the best movie ever made, it is certainly one of the sexiest (at least where the characters remain clothed). The humor throughout made this an enjoyable/amusing movie. I also appreciate the effort made to stay true to the books. On countless occasions, I have read a book and loved it only to go see the movie and be very disappointed with how far it strays from the book's storyline. It's also very curious that the characters seem to speak, act and look the way I imagined them as I read the book. The effects aren't Matrix-like, however they get the point across. While I don't often read books about vampires and werewolves, I can honestly say that I enjoyed the books more - mostly because I can create my own "movie" in my head. If you want a movie with a sexy male character then go see this one - Edward Cullen is one hot vampire!

It was fairly good. I am a die hard twilight fan so i was disappointed a little bit.I am fully aware that the movies are always different, but to me the movie was too rushed. I found that the way the movie was put together was also very choppy. Worth seeing if your a twilight fan, just Don't get your hopes up. A lot of major points didn't exist. :( A teenage romance full of awkwardness and laughs, but not up to par with the book. Kellan Lutz and Nikki Reed played their characters perfectly, with Billy Burke being one of the most interesting supporting characters to watch. If you decide to go, the second half of the film is much better than the first so make sure you sit it out. PS. When Edward first walks into the room, it was amazing!

Of course, looking back, you realize how fake, exaggerated and ridiculous everything is.

But as a teenager, I really like this movie.

I even empathized with the heroes and cried at some moments. Probably, the plot is due to the current themes and paintings of that time, but I still like it.

A typical "girly" movie. It will do for viewing a couple of times, well, and as a subject of nostalgia.

I am a 22 year old male. I read the book, and thought Twilight was pretty bad. It was clearly a book written for young girls, and has almost nothing to entice an older, male reader. It was extremely melodramatic, poorly written, and left out scenes that would be interesting to readers who are not enthralled by extremely hokey and immature teenage "love." That is not to say that I cannot appreciate love stories or chick flicks; I read Pride and Prejudice, and thought it wonderful. I started to read the books after the movie had already come out, and I had already heard the disappointing reviews, but I still was interested enough to rent the film, and invest 2 hours of my life into it. Like the book, the story was almost nonexistent, but that is okay! Like Pride and Prejudice, the relationships and the emotional response of the characters IS the story. I thought the casting was perfect, except for Kristen Stewart as Bella; she was unconvincing and unrealistic, but Robert Pattinson as Edward more than made up for her, which was enough to get me to buy into the romance, and Edward and Bella's real devotion to each other. For the special effects including the fast "vampire" walking, running through the woods, and even the sparkling in the sunlight, could not have been done any better. I have read a lot of complaints about them, but while reading the book, what was done in the movie was exactly what I visualized and expected. It would have been easy to overdo the jumping, and the climbing, and the sound effects when Edward was sparkling, but I think the director blended those effects naturally into the middle of the romance, without drawing too much attention to the effect itself. The soundtrack was excellent. The emo/punk rock sound was perfectly selected to reach out to the teen audience, but it was the sounds of Carter Burwell music that caught my attention, really adding to the eerie feel of Bella's situation. It also seemed to enhance the "falling in love" sequences, with the long scenes of beautiful music, beautiful scenery, and non-audible dialogue. The visually stunning scenery of Oregon really made the whole story seem out of this world, but the realism of all the characters makes it just believable enough be enticed. The writing was below par, and the immature high school scenes were a bit annoying, but did not distract me from the sexual tension between Edward and Bella, and seemed like more of a backdrop for the surreal world that Bella is really living in. Besides, what goes unsaid is far more important and revealing than the dialogue; this only seems to get you caught up in the you-wish-it-were-real romantic passion all the more. The movie appeals to a broader audience than the book, possible at the expense of disappointing its original fan base. It took me a while to return to the real world after spending 2 hours in a world of beautiful romance, which seems just realistic enough for viewers to not automatically dismiss it as too good to be true. Like the newest creation of Pride and Prejudice (with Keira Knightley), when watching Twilight, get ready to delve into a romantic and thrilling world that sucks you in, and makes you wish you didn't have to leave at the credits.

I'm a guy and I saw this movie and have since read the book. I'm not in love with the series but find it relatively compelling. I think it would be better if I had ever been a girl going through high school, but alas I went through it as a guy. I went to the movie because I know fan girls who love this series and wouldn't shut up about it. I don't like to judge these fads as I once liked Pokemon. I saw this movie not knowing anything about the series other than Edward is a vampire and Bella was in love with him. As someone who has not read the book the story was quite interesting. They made a pretty decent plot out of what they had to work with. Like I said I read the book later and was amazed at what they did. In the book, it felt like it was a turn of the page and Bella is in love with Edward where in the movie, I feel the progression felt more natural with less of the angst filled teenage girl feel. The acting is overdone but I feel it was intentional. If you've ever seen Speak with Kristen Stewart, you know she can act. I feel she probably was acting well and they asked her to stop. The camera never stops moving really unless the actors are moving around. I remember one scene where Bella is talking to Charlie in the kitchen and Bella is filling a glass with water and drinking it while her dad is eating his food. What grabbed me about that scene is I can't remember the dialog because they were moving around so much. There is always movement. I feel all of this was also done for their target audience: Angst filled teenage girls. Let's be realistic, that is who the film was intended for. That's who the books were written for. The camera never stops panning and the actors never stop movie because teenagers have ADD. Despite a myriad of flaws, the movie was still entertaining. It's not the next Lord of the Rings or anything but when I left, I didn't feel ripped off. Let's be realistic, most movies suck these days so just having a film that doesn't annoy me is an accomplishment.

review_title: Kristen and Rob made this movie
review_text: this movie is surprisingly a lot better than what i thought it would be.i read some reviews before i went, and i was kinda afraid.but i went in and enjoyed it very much.Robert pattinson did a great job as Edward, and so did Kristen Stewart as Bella.they both captured their characters from the book.now, i'm not saying this is an Oscar nominee movie because it isn't.i thought the screenplay was pretty cheesy at times,hardwicke could of done a little better directing, and most of the acting from the human high school kids was bad half the time but that was probably because of hardwicke and Rosenberg(screenplay writer).but Kristen and rob made up for that.they mostly made this movie.they both did a fantastic job bringing their characters to life.they also have great chemistry together.every time they were together in the film, it was intense.don't get me wrong, the actors playing the cullens did a great job, especially peter facinelli as carlisle.i truly think facinelli is the perfect actor for carlisle.he was really believable as the father figure of the cullens.i just wish he had more screen time.billy burke also did a fantastic job portraying Charlie.he did his character true justice.Taylor lautner did a lot better job playing Jacob than i thought he would do too.also, the actors playing the nomadic vampires did a good job overall, nothing spectacular but good.now, hardwicke, for the most part, stayed close to the storyline from the best-selling novel, but, for you twilight die hard fans, don't expect this film to be page for page or chapter for chapter.just enjoy it for what it is.i do think that they should get another screenplay writer for the sequels, but other than that, i am looking forward to them.

review_title: Entertaining - not the book, but I liked it =]
review_text:
Keep in mind that no movie is as good as its book. It's impossible, seriously. And two: The movie can never ruin a book and it can't take the place of a book. And don't compare the movie to the book, it's not totally fair anyway. On that note:

I really enjoyed myself. I'm one of those obsessive twilight freaks you either see buying shirts or read about. Nice to meet you.

I went into the theater cautious because of the reviews I'd read. However, I went out thinking I don't think I saw the same movie everyone else saw. Yes I did feel like parts of the book that were left out would have filled the holes I noticed, but it still was pretty good. The beginning of the movie was the worst part for me. I felt that there were a lot of holes and if I hadn't read the books, I'd have been a bit confused and rushed through. I didn't really like the changes in the Biology scene. But I'm okay with it. As far as the acting, I thought it was fine. Yes, a lot of people disagree which is fine but also sad. I think the acting deserves more credit than it's getting. Rob did a pretty good job playing Edward. Kristen did a good job at playing Bella. I really liked Cam as James, he did an excellent job as well did Rachelle. My favorite part of the movie was the baseball scene. I loved Muse's song during that scene and just how awesome it was. The baseball scene all the way to the end is the best part of the movie for me. I felt a bit sad about the awaited meadow scene as it really wasn't that scene I read in the book. And when Edward saves Bella in Port A. I felt giddy like I did reading the book.

Overall I thought the movie was good, maybe great, but not perfect. The thing that everyone seems to neglect is A. the movie didn't have the money that like Harry Potter or a Batman movie would get. It had to make do. B. It could have been a lot worse. Bella could have been changed completely as could have the other characters.

It's not fair to treat this movie with high class before it's viewing and than bash it when it is out. And it wasn't as bad as a lot of people are saying, those who may not even love the books as much as I do. Everyone needs to remember that there is a fine line between a book and the movie it is BASED off of. You will always love the book more.

I think that everyone should be thankful that Twilight is actually getting it's deserved attention and that a movie is made. Let's hope that negative comments won't ruin this film saga so the films can grow with time and money.

IF you're wondering if you should see it and you've read the book: Go see it. IT's not the book, so it can't ruin it. And it is a good film. I really enjoyed it and this is coming from one of those obsessive freaks =]

If you wondering if you should see it and you've not read the book: Go see it anyway. I will be honest and say I felt that if I hadn't read the book, there are plot holes. But that could just be because I read the book. My step mom saw it with me and hadn't read the book and she enjoyed it and got the main idea. And now she wants to read this book i've been trying to get her to read forever. So you may walk out wanting to read the magic that the film was based off of.

Thanks and keep an open mind. I really liked it. =]

I went into this movie with pretty low expectations. I mean, I was excited about it obviously, but the movie previews and the usage of Kristen Stewart as Bella had me on edge. I thought she was going to be too pretty for the part.

But I didn't have to fear. Within the first few minutes of the film, I was in love with Kristen Stewart's portrayal as Bella.

And don't even get me started with Robert as Edward... mmmmmm I am a huge Harry Potter fan, and I am a huge fan of the movies. Yet, I always leave the movie with some disappointment. I always say to myself, "Wow, I wish they would have included this small detail that is actually significant to the story." However, with Twilight, I felt like they did a fantastic job of paying attention to small details that I think all Twilight readers can appreciate: Edward's (and all of the Cullen's) golden eyes, the preexisting tension between the Black and Cullen families, including the lullaby, the WHOLE baseball scene, Alice's quirikiness, the dreamy "Dr. Cullen", etc. Too much to mention.

I don't know, I feel like I have seen a lot of responses regarding the inaccuracy of this movie, but I strongly suggest otherwise. You will appreciate the attention to small detail that really makes this movie what it is.

review_title: I was surprised... happily and sadly.
review_text:
All in all, TWILIGHT was a decent flick.

I am disappointed, though, in the choppy nature of the budding romance between Edward & Bella. I really think that 10 minutes of running time could have been added to the beginning of the film to clear things up a bit more than was done. If you read the book, you could easily infer what you already knew - but if you went in with no prior knowledge of the book, you may have been confused by the sudden intensity of Edward & Bella's relationship. It almost seemed to go from "talking" to "in love". It was rushed.

The rest of the movie flowed well. The chase and climax were done very well - better than the first part of the movie.

There was a lot of unexpected comic relief, which had me pleasantly surprised.

And I know Rob Pattinson fans are going to be angry at me for this, but his American accent was stiff and unconvincing. His cadence was off a bit and certain words sounded odd. I still think the man has amazing potential as an actor; he just needs some work with a speech coach for "New Moon" (if it gets made). And I cannot deny his screen presence. Even *I* swooned.

Kristen's Bella really surprised me. I ended up really liking her. I always thought Kristen had great potential; I am convinced of it now.

The rest of the cast was pretty amazing. Rosalie pulled off b&%$h extremely well. I loved Emmett. And I *adored* Jasper & Alice. *ADORED*. They were perfect! I liked Jacob more than I thought I would, his charisma and enthusiasm were catching.

All in all, if you like Twilight, you will most likely enjoy the movie. If you're a romantic at heart, looking for a good date movie or if you like vampires - you will probably like the movie. If you're a Twilight 'purist' - you are going to find flaws at every turn. Just go see it and enjoy it for what it is - if you don't have any expectations, you'll probably be pleasantly surprised!

Firstly, I admit to two facts: 1. I have read the Twilight saga (why did I bother? I am not sure - probably to see what all the fuss was about. Nothing it would seem) 2. I am not the target audience for this film but it is worth noting that the actors and director have made much of the fact that Twilight is not exclusively a 'teen' film. I would disagree with that. I cannot comprehend how anyone other than an impressionable teenage girl would enjoy this farcical romp.

Twilight is simply dire and for so many reasons. It could have been decent - there were glimpses of what could have been a good film but they were few and far between. Mostly this film is a mess, cringe-worthy and funny for all the wrong reasons. Some key observations:

1. Style: The film looks and feels disjointed - like it is a mash up of clips shot by different people. Some scenes are shot in awkward hand-held camera mode, as though it is a student 'mockumentary'. Other scenes (the majority I would say) have a substandard teen soap quality about them. The two former styles mean that the baseball and ballet studio scenes (both of which I quite enjoyed - particularly the baseball scene, which was odd in the book but done very well here) seem out of place. I appreciate that the budget was low on this film but even still! The lack of continuity in film style is perplexing and irritating.

2. Storyline: The film tried to stick to as much of the book as possible but as much of the book focus on Bella's inner thoughts/inner monologues, it meant that the script jumped from scene to scene awkwardly without any explanation. Maybe a loose adaptation would have been better.

3. Soundtrack: I found the use of music in this film to be utterly bizarre. In many scenes the music just seemed inappropriate or completely random/out of sync. Some of the more 'intense' scenes between Bella and Edward were ruined by odd background music/random guitar chords. The scene where Edward plays the piano befits a music video rather than a film. Odd.

4. Acting Or lack of: Sorry, but most of the people in this film are painfully wooden and dull. I feel bad for Robert Pattinson - he does an alright job but because everyone else is so poor (I know Bella is a bit dull in the books, but Kristen Stewart is just annoying and monotonous in tone and acting) he looks out of sorts and almost like he is over acting when he is actually the only one acting!

Twilight could have been something decent (not that the story line is particularly original, but even so) but in the end I don't think it even qualifies as a 'film'. I have given it 3 stars and not 1 because I liked the use of Radiohead at the end, the baseball scene was surprisingly well done and Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart at least looked the part. Other than that, I have to shake my head in shame. What a lost opportunity. Seeing as the books go downhill from here on, I can't imagine what the other films will be like. Be prepared to cringe and be disappointed I reckon.

Firstly to say is that I didn't read any of the Twilight novels, so I just can't compare this movie to the book and secondly I just saw this movie for the hype my friends gave regarding the Twilight novels and to be frank, this movie just made me glued to the screen till its running time so am not going to write anything negative regarding this movie as I didn't still read the novel yet.

I believe Stephanie Meyer took an easy path in to writing a romantic novel because romantic novels always appeal to lot of people. But the description given for each romantic scene and the chemistry appealed well to me. Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart had a very good screen time together(Can't say the same with their performances as both are very young actors but they looked good as the lead couple in the movie).

Carter Burke did a fine Job as Kirsten Stewart's dad and he gave a pretty decent performance compared to the lead actors. The plot was nothing extra-ordinary. It was a Fantasy-Romance type but the fantasy was kept subtle as possible to make way for a more romantic movie as the novel promised I believe.

Taylor Lautner didn't have much screen time but kept as just another actor in this movie. Seeing this movie made me feel like not all vampires are blood-thirsty repulsive hideous type. There are some super-cool ones like the Cullens too.

The story is that Bella Swan(Kirsten Stewart) comes to Forks to live with her divorced dad Charlie Swan(Carter Burke) after her mom decides to travel with her newly married husband Phil who is a baseball pro. Like all the college movies you would've seen the new guy gets a bunch of friends who'll come and go now and then. This one isn't so different either.

One day Bella sees the Cullens, a weird gang in her high school. First thing she sets sight on Edward Cullen(Robert Pattinson), Its love all the way. Cullens are vampires but they don't have that thirst for human blood like most vampires do and so they live peacefully among the people at Forks. Edward also gets drawn to Bella by many-a-coincidences and both of them fall Head-over-heels in love with each other with romantic dialogues thrown here and there in good measure(Hats off! Stephanie Meyer. They were totally awesome!).

In between all this romance, there was a thriller waiting to unfold as 3 vampires Laurent(Edi Gathegi), James(Cam Gigandet) and Victoria(Rachelle Lefevre) hunt people for their blood thirst and Police investigation goes on like some animal is killing people at Forks. Bella and Edward get very close and Edward even takes her to introduce to the other members of his Vampire family.

The Cullens and Bella get along well and one fateful day the paths of Cullens and those 3 vampires cross due to one vampire, James, drawn to the scent of Bella swan and he'll stop at nothing to have his snack a.k.a Bella Swan. After this comes a climax where Bella and Edward get separated due to the intensity of the situation and the Cullens make some plans to distract James but James was too smart for them and gets to Bella.

The Hero, Edward Cullen finally comes to the rescue of Bella(as predictable as always) and saves her after she gets bitten by James by sucking the Venom out of her. Though Edward gets a chance to change Bella in to a Vampire, he remains controlled and restores her normalcy. James gets killed by the Cullens adding to the sorrow of Victoria who vows to take on the Cullens later in the name of James. End of the story.

So I'll recommend this movie for all those who all are too lazy to read novels but can enjoy hours and hours of time in front of a TV or PC. In the end you'll say, "It wasn't that bad!".

My Verdict- Twilight 6.5/10

This movie is good ! I really like it; the fact that finally people make vampire movies were (some) vampires are good. This,the True Blood HBO series and of course Queen of the Damned.

The story isn't bad at all, a love story between a vampire and a human girl, the slight rejection and the huge attraction between them, the love and the retain from killing.

I haven't read the book and even though the movie plays for 2 hours, I do believe it must be longer. Or maybe everything happens to fast. From the "Hello, my name is Eduard" to the " You are my life now" is like 3 weeks (because prom was in a month at the start of the movie). But who knows, life can be different as a vampire in love.

I really enjoyed the fact that there aren't any huge and fantasy-like special effects. It makes everything look real, believable. People are not exaggerated, there aren't any spoiled brats mean girls, there are good people, normal people.

You don't see vampires really killing in this movie, there is a scene but it's subtle. Interesting fact really, because you never see fangs and the bite on Bella's hand is like a normal human bite. There is action in the movie,pretty good one really, but not to much, because it is focused on the connection between the two main characters.

I liked the fact that there is no sex scene in the movie, no major kissing, and still the love and passion between the two main characters can be seen really good. It's so subtle and yet so obvious. I believe this because in every movie made these days, that involves love, sex is everywhere, after the first date, at the first kiss, it happens so fast, no wonder kids these days loose them self's so early.

Yes, the movie was a clich√©, but let's face it, how many movies have you watched lately that wasn't.

But I do hope that the vampire character won't be changed anymore in future movies, like it was changed in this one. Vampires walking on daylight is kinda enough, because it will ruin every fact about them with which we were raised with.

I will say it again: I LOVE the fact that I can see a vampire movie, where some vampires aren't on the bad side. For the watchers that enjoy vampire story's and are fascinated by this, it's a good feeling to watch this movie.

It isn't extraordinary, it isn't super good, but it's worth it, every 122 minutes of it.

review_title: Vampires of the World ... Avenge yourselves
review_text:
First of all I have to admit that I have never heard about the books before this movie, after seeing the movie I would not read those books even if I get paid to do so.

The story line seems directed at very young girls, so I was kinda of reluctant to see the movie, but I am such a fan of vampires (Louis, Lestat, Buffy, Angel, Spike, Selene), I thought that I might as well give it a shot.

I was greatly disappointed. The plot of a deadly dangerous "boy" fall for the "damsel in distress" and protect her with his life against all the dangers of the world, including himself ¬Ö is romantic and dreamy.

However, the movie turns out to be a huge disappointment and downright ridiculous.

The love scenes between the two main characters are too long and boring, they lack depth, warmth and credibility, he just popped every now and then by her side and told her to stay away from him, she finds out he is a vampire (a reasonably enough deduction! Vampires are known for a fact to exist among us) and fell hopelessly and irrevocably in love with him. I find that I don't relate to them at all. Kong had more passion and facial expressions for God's sake.

Edward has the appeal of a cardboard, he did not strike me as particularly dangerous or brooding, he looked depressed, rather psychotic and severely malnourished. And the speech of "I am the world most dangerous predator¬Ö' Could he be more ridiculous. Oh yes and he glitters in the sun too! Bella, why did she all the time look like she's just smelled something disgusting? And what is all the stammering and umms and ohhhs and uhs? And here I am a young girl in a strange town and a vampire comes to me and tells me that I smell so good he cannot resist eating me, do I get a little scared, worried ... at all ... not even a little, NO I trust him utterly and completely and throw myself in his arms, putting not only myself but my father as well in danger.

ALL other characters were underdeveloped so there is absolutely no way to judge them, the only prominent feature about them is how bad their makeup was, the faces were too white, this is beyond pale, like they've used flour, and the makeup artist did not even bother to cover all the way down their necks or their ears, and God ... way too much lipsticks. Not to mention the hair, isn't it kick-you-in-the-crotch painful to look at those hair styles. And the Cullens, they tried to be oh-so-dangerous and "vampiry" but they ended up being laughable, strained and ridiculous. I only liked the evil vampires, although again, they were way underdeveloped.

Special effects sucked big time, if I wanted a fast forward bleary motion to show me how fast these guys are, I would have just pressed fast forward on my set.

And why was it only Edward who could suck the venom out of Bella, especially when he is in such danger not to be able to stop, why not Carlisle or Alice. I guess it was only to deliver the silliest scene ever, the expression on Edward's face was priceless.

I have never ever ever in my life heard such a ridiculous script ¬Ö never ¬Ö ever ... EVER "Are you going to tell me how you stopped the van? Yeah. Um, I had an adrenaline rush. It's very common. You can Google it" ¬Ö" I only said it would be better if we weren't friends, not that I didn't want to be. What does that mean? It means if you're smart, you'll stay away from me. Okay, let's say for argument's sake that I'm not smart"¬Ö I could go on. Have you ever heard of "We'll always have Paris" or even "You complete me"??!!!?? Where are the aspects that we all love in a vampire movie; dangerous lurking in the night, flinching from the cross, avoiding the sunlight for reasons that does not involve sparkles and glitters, stakes, and fangs ... where are the fangs??? Even just dangerous looking teeth would have satisfied me. I think in this movie vampires will suck your blood dry by simply staring you to death.

So vampire and wolves, my two most favorite creatures of the night have been totally butchered, ridiculed and distorted in this awful ridiculous awful stupid awful movie.

I don't recommend this movie to anyone, in fact I recommend that whoever participated in this movie, even remotely, anyone who was present within two blocks from where they were filming that movie should be set to be eaten by wolves or better yet by vampires ... they really deserve a chance to avenge their tarnished reputation.

The film moved slowly and painfully. The story dragged along like a wet rag. It was tedious and the acting by the lead characters, had no passion, no sense of drama and no delivery. There was no build up or tension supposed to be conveyed by their forbidden love. I thought that the lead character Edward was supposed to be a handsome, sophisticated vampire, but was sadly disappointed by the unattractive choice in Robert Patterson. Bella, attractive enough even with all the white pasty makeup couldn't stoke the fires in even the most undead with her unconvincing performance of a love struck teen. Definitely steer clear of this movie, bad special effects, cheesy dialog and full of 'cringe' moments where the scenes are so bad you can help but shun your eyes. A huge sleeper.

review_title: A great movie that IS NOT just for teens
review_text: Right, I've read quite a few comments before I have decided to add mine. I watched the movie last night and OMG I really enjoyed it. Everything about it was great. It is a great entertainment and I would recommend it to all my friends.

This movie is absolutely horrible. The things in the movie (as well in the book) are very funny. To the point that it makes me crack up. The dialogue is very poor-written, the plot is all over the place, and just the whole of the movie is very bad. I was laughing the whole entire time. The ONLY reason I even rated it 2 stars is because it gets to the point that it's so bad that it's just a little good. Jasper, in my opinion, is the funniest of them all. I will have to say that they did better than I expected on the wolves. I would not recommend watching this disgrace of a movie. I would also not recommend reading the book, either, for it is even worse then the movie.

review_title: The Hype, The Reality, The Movie
review_text:
I have a somewhat unique perspective on Twilight. I didn't know about it until a few months ago when I saw a teaser-trailer. So, rather than immediately give in to the hype surrounding it, I decided to try an experiment. I bought the book, but didn't read it. I waited until the movie came out, watched the movie, read the book and then watched the movie again. So, I can honestly say I've seen the movie from multiple perspectives. I have just recently finished reading the next three books in the series so my knowledge about the series is fairly well-rounded.

So, first of all, is Twilight a great film? Sadly, no. It's a...good film. It is a solid "C+" effort. And it will probably wear slightly better once the hype wears off and the audience calms a little (i.e., DVD/Blu-Ray sales). The hype storm surrounding the movie is part of the problem. People started expecting so much of this rather small-budgeted *teen* movie that the movie itself failed to meet the somewhat extraordinary expectations. Twilight = $37 million; by contrast Harry Potter 1 = $125 million. Get the difference? I didn't want to compare the two franchises, but it does seem rather impossible to avoid. Sorry.

I know people say they understand that film and print are two different media, but when one invests so much time in a single medium (print) it is difficult to divest oneself of the connection. So the secondary medium (film) will always be worse. It takes a conscious effort to remove the print expectations from the film and it can be difficult. In this case, it actually should have been easier than it seems to be for a lot of people.

When I first saw the movie (before reading the book) I was...let's say, less than impressed. I probably wouldn't have even given it the C rating I now do. Without knowing the story, the film could easily be conceived as jagged -- the pace was certainly too fast by half. However, I followed through on my experiment and am now grateful I did. Please remember, this was a five hundred page book. You will lose things -- important things -- in the translation to a two-hour movie. It is inevitable.

However, the reason I say the translation should have been easier is because I also give the *book* a C (some days a B-). I am a Harry Potter girl and I have spent a good chunk of time over the last ten years (Good God, has it seriously been ten years?) reading and beta-reading fanfiction. Now, the Twilight story itself is a good one and the universe Stephenie Meyer created is also intriguing, but it almost reads as fanfiction to me. It certainly carries that flavor. *Good* fanfiction -- better than probably 99% out there currently (and I would know). However, please, someday, do what I did -- pick up Harry Potter and the Philosopher's/Sorcerer's Stone again. I can easily remember why I was so unimpressed with the Harry Potter series until book 3.

Twilight is not great literature, but there is a lot of space between the great American novel and bad writing and the Twilight series fits in that spectrum somewhere toward the former. And I find myself understanding the movie more after having read the series. I think the book rating and the film rating are roughly on par with one another and can easily be related. Which is why I'm giving it a C+ rating.

Now, forget the book. Let's talk movie.

To begin, it is a Romeo/Juliet, paranormal *romantic* teen movie. Bear that in mind. It didn't attempt to be so much more than that because that is the universe it exists in.

The acting was a solid B average; in some places it was more, in some it was less. The chemistry between the leads is apparent from the first moment they're in the frame together. This lends the movie a nice head start because Bella and Edward are what the series is about. So, once they've got that chemistry, the filmmakers are already ahead. I think, in general, the casting choices were great, but some of the lines they were given to act were...not so great. Again, that kind of fanfiction feel to it; and even great actors can have difficulty with moronic dialogue (to which the screenplay occasionally degenerates). And remember, the two leads are still in the infancy of their careers. Give them some time to mature.

And yes, the special effects were simplistic but so what? Since when are special effects necessary to make a movie worthwhile? I rather like the fact that it had a smaller budget for such a hyped-up movie. Remember, $37 million. A week of rehearsals and 44 days of principal photography. Knowing the numbers, I'm even more impressed.

And just as a note on a few bits of the praiseworthy: thank you to Robert Pattinson for getting his accent down perfectly. It is a difficult thing to act with any accent, let alone a subtle one that is so far removed from the natural voice. Also to Kristen Stewart who played a lovestruck teen girl to perfection without being any more annoying than necessary (excepting perhaps one scene).

This movie is what it seems to be. A teen romance with a paranormal edge and smaller budget. Try not to compare it to things it cannot be compared to¬Öincluding the book. You'll just end up disappointed. Accept the movie as is and enjoy what is there to enjoy. You'll be much happier, anyway.

Honestly, I wasn't expecting much since id viewed the trailers on youtube several times. I didn't want to get my hopes up too much for this movie and I think it was a bit more then i expected.

Everyone complains about how bad it was but honestly, people need to not compare it EXACTLY to the book. For those who are Twilight readers, you shouldn't complain so much. I think the problem is that those who have read the book expect so much since they picture everything perfectly in their head, since thats what Bella and Edward's relationship is made out to be.

I'll admit when i went to the midnight showing Thursday into Friday, I did come out slightly comparing it to the book. People need to give the director props for trying to make such a popular book into a movie. There NEEDS to be changes in scenes or humor or dialogue and people should realize that also. Not everyone going to this movie has read the book, therefore there needs to be a slight change.

Others complain that Robert and Kristen's acting did even compare to that of the book (again with the comparing people!) but if Kristen were to narrate as Bella the whole more just to describe her feelings for Edward I think we'd all agree the move would get boring.

All in all I think the movie was most on the book and I don't care if it wasn't exactly the same. My imagination is different to anyone else's. Acting was decent and the way they shot scenes was just okay too. I plan on going back again to get my finial opinion of the movie.

I did love how they created the baseball scene! Also, LOVED the forshadowing to the other novels ;) Overall definitely a guilty pleasure...that I'll be watching many, many times!

It is intimate and very like I can't live without you kind of thing. I've read the books and I think it portrayed the two of them quite well, although there aren't so many dazzling moments between them the moments that were in the movie i really liked. Its not so much the story thats important here but how Bella and Edward are to each other and i think that shows quite well especially in the end of the movie. They do have a different relationship so this is a different movie and you should definitely go and see it!! its good, touching and a bit funny too at times, go see it!! and remember there's a sequel, this is just the beginning of the two of them:)

review_title: I haven't been this happy about an adaptation of a book since Lord of the Rings
review_text:
Did I love it? Did it measure up to the hype? Did it honor the book? Was he Edward? Yes, yes, yes, YES!!! Yesterday afternoon, I went with four other moms to see Twilight. The mom next to me had serious doubts that Robert Pattinson could live up to the Edward Cullen of the book, especially after she saw some of the clips of Robert doing goofy interviews. She was totally won over by his performance. "He IS Edward!" The first thing she said after the movie ended was, "I want to see it again!" I totally agree, and may even be seeing it again tonight with my hubby.

Yes, I felt like one of those teenage girls again even though I'm 43. I swooned over Robert Pattinson's James Dean cool. He's the bad boy, and you can't help but fall in love.

This movie is a romance! It's Romeo and Juliet. It's Heathcliff and Cathy. It's the modern take on star-crossed love. In modern times, how else do you keep those young lovers apart? All the complaints from male reviewers about special effects that weren't top notch, not enough action, not enough blood, not enough scariness. You don't get it. This movie is not for your demographic. This is not an action film with a few minutes of romance thrown in to get the women to come. This is a romance, a full on old fashioned, say those lines with sincerity and not mocking, ROMANCE with a few minutes of action and peril thrown in. Bella is only in danger so Edward can save her like a white knight! I can't say enough about the performances of Robert Pattinson as Edward, and Kristen Stewart as Bella. They WERE Edward and Bella, and got the tone exactly right. Robert, I thought, played Edward a little more depressed than in the book, maybe foreshadowing New Moon, but it felt right to me. He just oozed anguish with every line, "What if I'm the bad guy?" Swoon! Melissa Rosenberg, the screenwriter, gets my ultimate respect and kudos. It is not an easy thing to adapt a novel that has such a fervid following, and she did a great job. She captured the essence. You can't have everything included, and some things need to be different to play on screen. The best example is how she combined the meadow scene where Edward reveals his diamond skin, with the first time that Bella says to Edward that he is a vampire, which I believe in the book is in the car. Combining the two together made it much more dramatic and worked extremely well. The diamond skin in sunlight special effect wasn't as radiant and glowing as I'd pictured in my mind, but given their budget looked good. With more money for New Moon, it will be interesting how the special effects improve. There will be a lot of them with all the werewolf changing! I loved how Cathy Hardwicke captured the relationship between Bella and her father, Charlie. It was pitch perfect. Cathy Hardwicke, the director who made Thirteen, made her best choices in the casting. I can't think of one single person who was "off". And her finds in Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson! Kristen Stewart she saw in Into The Wild, a film I have not seen. Hardwicke has said, "I felt her yearning -- it was just palpable," and it is that quality that sets the tone for the entire film. That was just what was needed for Bella. It's all those looks she gives when she's not even saying anything! Even Stephenie Meyer, the author of Twilight, had doubts about Robert Pattinson as Edward, because in real life he is a goof and kind of shy. She said that once a scene would start, he was instantly transformed to Edward and he exceeded her expectations. My God, that intensity smolders right off the screen, and even his "crooked grin" felt just right.

I don't think I have been as happy about the adaptation of a book to screen since Lord of the Rings. They did it. They made something the fans of the book can love. All those thirteen year old girls will be seeing this film multiple times, and I will be, too.

All the stories I read about the box office predictions talked about how unique this film's demographic is and how difficult it was to predict how huge it would be. Is it really? It's not a "family film" like Nancy Drew or Harry Potter. It's not a video game adaptation for teen boys. It's not a Rom Com. It's not Sex and the City which is for women, but an older demographic. It really was funny to me that this seemed to be the first movie for girls, but for older women, too. Let's hope it starts a trend. We girls and women have money to spend, too, and a hunger for romance. Are you listening studio heads?

review_title: Tone and Screenplay fail Solid Leads
review_text:
Incredibly lazy work by Rosenberg who looking at her resume is not new to screen writing. Therefore there is absolutely no excuse for putting in unnecessary voice overs or extraneous dialogue in moments where the emotion or meaning was already insinuated through actors & action. Felt like a second draft. Less than impressive, I felt the two solid leads were given little to work from.

Also the tone of the film was bizarre at moments, uncertain direction from Hardwicke which is again disappointing considering the caliber of some of her other films.

It was a good way to waste an afternoon thanks to a charismatic cast but I ultimately ended up leaving frustrated because of elemental flaws that should have been picked up by at least a producer or script supervisor.
